The quicker treatment could eventually contribute to improved outcomes for mothers and preterm infants while also providing a higher chances of success with this treatment.

# Procedure
As the betamethasone treatment is usually administered before delivery, a betamethasone regimen needs to be initiated and administered. As a drug, betamethasone is designed to be injected into the patient’s muscle. A proper betamethasone administration would require the attending physician or nurse to inject 1.2 mg of betamethasone into the patient's muscles.
Once the betamethasone treatment has been initiated. The treatment may take approximately one to two days to be effective in helping to close the patient's ductus arteriosus. Patients who had a higher birth weight should be able to go through the treatment more successfully as a higher birth weight should provide better nutrition for the patient to maintain a constant weight while going through this treatment.
A patient’s gestational age should also be important to the betamethasone treatment outcome in terms of determining if the ductus arteriosus will close. Clinical trial research trends in India: A ten year bibliometric analysis of the International Clinical Trials Registry Platform (ICTRP)

The International Clinical Trials Registry Platform (ICTRP) is a global registry of clinical trials. This paper is the first attempt to analyze the clinical trial trend in India, using the ICTRP search engine. It analyzes the clinical trials data of ICTRP between 2012 and 2019. It provides an analysis of 1457 clinical trials that met the ICTRP search criteria. These had been approved by ethics committee and funded by government and industry. It provides details of all 13 registry platforms that met the search criteria and their relative share. It provides an analysis of trial characteristics using descriptors like 'trial' status 'phase', 'multicenter' trial, 'sample size', 'informed consent', 'funding agency' and 'participating centre'. It identifies most common diseases, top drugs and devices as well as most common interventions and comparators. It analyzes the international collaborative nature of the trials. This provides a comprehensive picture of clinical research in India.

# Introduction
India's clinical research has been growing at a healthy pace in the last two decades. Indian scientists have been actively collaborating internationally, increasing their visibility in the global arena. India is now considered as second in Asia and 1 3 th globally (after USA, China) in clinical research. The International Clinical Trials Registry Platform (ICTRP) is the world's first central portal for information on clinical trials. It is an international effort headed by the World Health Organization and in collaboration with several institutions from around the globe. The ICTRP search engine helps clinical researchers explore clinical trials published across 13 clinical trial registry platforms from around the globe. The details are available in the ICTRP database at WHO's website. ClinincalTrials.gov was included in ICTRP in 2005. The other 12 registries include EU-CTR, ANZCTR, ISCTRP (International Standard Serial Number Registry),

Morinda lucida Benth is a west African medicinal plant used for the treatment of various ailments like rheumatism, pain and inflammation and has been extensively used as a remedy for cancer. In addition, some reports have proven the effectivity of the root extract of the plant in various pain models. e present study evaluates the effectivity of morpholine 6 and 8, two isolated trinorditerpenoids, in mice models of nociception and paw inflammation using a hot plate and a formalin test respectively. Our results revealed an effectiveness of 8 in the formalin test and 6 in the warm water induced flinching. As for their anti-inflammatory activity, both compounds had some effect, but morpholine 6 had a more intense effect on carrageenan-induced paw edema. ese results corroborate those revealed with crude extract and pure isolated fractions from M. lucida.

Background: The human microbiome is dynamic and changes across the lifespan due to both host-related factors and environmental variation. The taxonomic composition of the human microbiome can also be affected by diseases such as inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and cancer. We have analyzed gut microbiome samples from 201 individuals aged 0-74 years of age to compare the microbial taxonomic composition in the intestines of healthy and diseased individuals. Results: We used amplicon sequencing to analyze the gut microbiome composition in each sample and we used our analysis pipeline to compare the taxonomic composition of the human intestinal communities and to determine which phyla are overrepresented or underrepresented in each sample.Conclusions:We found the intestinal microbial populations to have greater variability between individuals as compared to the microbiota from their local environment, which indicates that there are host-specific contributions to the intestinal microbiota composition. Our analysis pipeline is freely available and can be used to compare the microbiome populations of the human intestines to each other or to those of other bodily sites. We have released our dataset as part of the open-access Open-CARV human microbiome resource (http://open-carv.org).

The first objective of this paper is to present the general theory of planned behaviour. This theoretical approach allows explaining the intention to adopt healthy or harmful behaviours by the two components of the social cognition model. The second objective is to apply this model to the explanation of the behaviour of women in the context of the prevention of cardiovascular diseases. The third objective is to use the health belief model to understand the effects of the perceived barriers and benefits on the intention. Two studies have been conducted. The first concerned a general population composed mostly of women; the second was a clinical study on menopausal women. The results show that the variables of the "behavioural control" in the planned behaviour construct are the main factors that explain adherence to a healthy lifestyle by a population of women or by menopausal women, when they present risk factors for cardiovascular diseases. The main barriers and the benefits for cardiac rehabilitation were found, respectively, as perceived obstacles to the adoption of healthy practices and perceived benefits, thus explaining the intention for a cardiac rehabilitation programme. Reciprocity between transcription factor binding in yeast and expression in a human cell line

Background: Transcription factor binding and gene expression are influenced by the identity of binding sites and the expression of the transcription factors, respectively. In this report, we combine biochemical methods to study transcription factor binding, and transcript profiling using the Saccharomyces genome database (yeast genome data) and the Yale cDNA microarray database (Coriell Institute, in vitro data from human cells).Results:We found a strong correlation between the presence of a transcription factor binding site and expression level of the cognate transcription factor. This relationship was observed in both transcriptional responses to a glucose stimulus, or response to heat shock. We found that the presence of a YAP1 binding site was correlated with YAP1 mRNA levels in different transcriptional contexts. An interaction network between YAP1 and its target genes was constructed. The network analysis indicates that genes regulated by YAP1 have been conserved throughout evolution. To our knowledge, our study is the first to demonstrate a direct relationship between transcription factor binding and expression in human cells from gene microarray data.Conclusion

The impact of a low-cost intervention on improving oral health status among children in a community-based program

Background: Oral diseases are among the most common chronic diseases in children, impacting oral health and quality of life. To date, interventions to improve pediatric oral health have relied upon the delivery of intensive, resource-intensive programs. However, such programs have not been able to be duplicated in non-clinical care settings, where many children receive preventive care in community-based programs. Methods: This project will evaluate the impact of a simple oral health intervention on the oral health status of children aged 1 -3 years participating in Head Start programming. This program, designed to enhance oral health among preschool children in Head Start settings, included weekly implementation of dental health screenings, as well as brief, low-cost toothbrushing with fluoride toothpaste, and dental sealants for at-risk children. The intervention will be implemented for 18 months at ten Head Start locations, with ten Head Start locations serving as reference cohorts. Study staff will train the site staff on how to implement the intervention over three visits. A convenience sample of children ages 1 -3 years (n = 1086) will be recruited from the Head Start sample and evaluated at baseline and month 9 using the oral examination portion of the Centers for Disparities Research and Training Development (CDR&T) Oral Health Protocol. Outcomes will include the percent of sealed teeth, clinical oral health status, plaque (PI), and gingivitis (GI). All data will be collected by trained study personnel using the CDR&T Oral Health Protocol, and data will be blinded and entered into a REDCap online data capture system. Data analysis will follow a pre-post comparison of the intervention and reference cohort groups, and will assess for differences using the Mann-Whitney U Test. # Methods

## Subjects and setting
The sample comprised 60 consecutive patients, (24 male and 36 female, age 21 -58), admitted to an outpatient rehabilitation unit for the treatment of shoulder pain of nontraumatic origin, for the period from 2009 to 2010. Subjects had not yet been treated. Subjects were divided into two subgroups that were treated with osteopathic treatment (Group 1) or conventional physiotherapy (Group 2).
The inclusion criteria for the whole sample were the following: nontraumatic shoulder pain and duration of at least 6 weeks, at least 18 years, pain with an intensity level > 5, inability to work, and exclusion of the presence of a neurological disorder, musculoskeletal condition or other conditions requiring immediate treatment or surgical intervention. After the surgical intervention, the blood vessels in the area of injury become abnormally dilated to allow for influx of plasma proteins and blood clotting factors. This inflammatory response is a critical step in establishing hemostasis and wound healing. To assess how quickly the blood vessels return to normal, we can measure the size of the vessels and the amount of blood flow using a laser Doppler flow sensor device. This system works by examining the variation in the Doppler signal, or the frequency shift of the emitted soundwave, which indicates the volume of blood flowing through a vessel. Another option is to examine the inflammatory process and how it affects the blood vessels within the tissue. During the inflammatory response, tissue fluid and proteins are present in excess, which can impact the normal blood flow. To measure the blood vessels and blood flow within the tissue, we can use a laser Doppler blood flow sensor. This device measures and analyzes the Doppler frequency shift to determine the velocity of the blood flow. It can be used to collect data in the frequency domain, which describes the magnitude and phase of the Doppler harmonic peaks. Learn about the FOSI Questionnaire
The Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy questionnaire (FACT-O), one of the most widely used assessment tools in ovarian cancer-focused research, is often used in clinical studies and has been shown to have excellent reliability and validity.
However, it was recently replaced with the FOSI, and while it’s also widely used in research, it hasn’t yet been compared with the FACT-O in the context of an ovarian cancer clinical trial.
What Is FOSI?
FOSI was developed by the University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, and it measures symptoms like pain, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, cramping, and bloating..
Additionally, the questionnaire has been used in both clinical trials and observational studies to assess quality of life in women with ovarian cancer.
In the current clinical trial, a study of the combination therapies niraparib plus pembrolizumab in comparison to niraparib alone in the treatment of patients with recurrent epithelial ovarian, fallopian tube, or primary peritoneal cancer, FOSI will be used to measure whether or not the combination therapies help to improve the quality of life and patient outcomes.
The trial begins with a baseline assessment of patients using the FACT-O, and then after the niraparib treatment period, during both single-agent niraparib therapy and combination therapy, FOSI is used at weeks 8, 20, 32, 44, and 56 in order to measure the effectiveness of niraparib as a treatment, the efficacy of combination therapies, and the patients’ ability to maintain positive quality of life indicators.
In these study settings, FOSI is an effective tool to help researchers, physicians, and the other clinicians involved measure the quality of life and other outcomes among patients in clinical trials related to ovarian cancer.

Identification of Two Subgroups of Atypical Vocal Flexibility During Development
Atypical vocal flexibility (AVF) refers to the impairment of voice fundamental frequency (F0) coordination between different vocal modes, often involving an excessive change in F0 relative to the context (i.e., overflexibility), and an erratic or absent change in F0 (i.e., inflexibility). Previous research has revealed high prevalence (approximately 25%) and severity (i.e., pervasive occurrence and magnitude of AVF) in children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). In the current study, we aimed to identify subgroups (subtypes) of AVF in 73 children with ASD (ages 3–13 years old, 75.3% males, 68.5% non-Hispanic White). We quantitatively rated the occurrence of AVF in each vocalization and assigned each child to subgroups based on AVF severity and pervasiveness using a new software. Results demonstrated that the children with ASD were not equally distributed across one or two AVF subgroups, but two profiles emerged, each with different prevalence rates (proportion of children with the profiles) and severity/pervasiveness levels (quantity of AVF in each child). The two subgroups were distinguished by the quantity of AVF in nonsocial conversation, nonsocial play, simple request, and complex request. One subgroup exhibited relatively high occurrence of AVF across all tasks, but the quantity of AVF varied according to the type of task. The other group was characterized by a lower count of AVF but exhibited more pervasive AVF compared with the others. Taken together, our findings suggest that children with ASD can be distinguished based on the severity and pervasiveness of AVF, suggesting potential clinical significance in assessing the severity and pervasiveness of AVF across various tasks and in tracking changes over time. As such, we hope the current findings will encourage researchers

Interleukin (IL)-7 is a pleiotropic cytokine of the 4 α-helix bundle family that is predominantly produced by lymphoid tissue stroma. In early stages of human ontogenesis, IL-7 is required for lymphocyte development and cell homeostasis, including growth, survival, and differentiation. On the other hand, IL-7 can support memory T-cell generation and survival in peripheral organs. IL-7 is also implicated in the reprogramming of T-cell metabolism, thus affecting T-cell differentiation. Not surprisingly, IL-7 has been described as pleiotropic cytokine both in health and disease. In autoimmune diseases (ADs), IL-7 is produced by several cells, including dendritic cells (DCs), T cells, and fibroblasts, and its expression increases in inflamed organs. Moreover, circulating levels of IL-7 were correlated with disease severity. In this regard, the use of IL-7 as a disease-modifying drug in AD is supported by preliminary data demonstrating a substantial decrease of pathogenic T cells and B cells in vivo. Furthermore, studies with IL-7 in mice have been described in transgenic models of multiple sclerosis (MS). In this article, we present an extensive overview of the biological properties of IL-7 and we discuss the impact of targeting this cytokine for the treatment of AD, focusing on therapeutic potential versus adverse effects. Nosocomial fungal infections are important health problem. Candida species, especially Candida Auris are most invasive organism causing infections in neutropenic patients. The present study is intended to detect the prevalence of various invasive candidiasis in neutropenic febrile patients, evaluate clinical manifestations and antifungal susceptibility pattern. This prospective study was conducted at department of Microbiology, Era Lucknow Medical College and Hospital, Lucknow, India. Blood and urine samples from 85 neutropenic febrile patients were collected and subjected to inoculate in Sabouraud's dextrose agar and incubated at 27°C for 24-48 h. Positive fungal isolates were identified microscopically by lactophenol cotton blue mount and identified by colonial character, microscopic, physiological and biochemical methods. Blood isolates were subcultured on chocolate agar, incubated at 37°C for 24-48h and their susceptibility was determined by using modified Kirby-Bauer disk diffusion technique. Among 85 patients, Candidiasis was detected in 11 patients (12.86%) and two had multiple species of candidiasis. Candida tropicalis 4 (36.4%) was major causative organism followed by Candida parapsilosis (36.3%), Candida glabrata (18.1%), Candida albicans (9.09%). Major clinical manifestations include fever, vomiting, diarrhoea, loss of appetite and weight loss. A randomized clinical trial is a method of research in which the participants are assigned to receive experimental or control treatments based on the outcome of a randomization process. This method of investigation helps minimize bias and uncertainty in evaluating the efficacy of a drug or other medical intervention. Furthermore, randomized clinical trials are widely accepted as the gold standard for establishing medical treatment efficacy. To conduct a randomized clinical trial one must identify the sample size and design the inclusion and exclusion criteria. Additionally, the investigator must randomize the participants and measure outcomes prior to the intervention. Moreover, the trial must be monitored and supervised by clinical experts, who determine its quality and impact. In conclusion, the investigation of randomized clinical trials can provide essential evidence for the evaluation of medical interventions.

The influence of preoperative factors on graft size in free‐flap breast reconstruction
Despite improvements in imaging modalities that may be used for determining graft size, accurate breast volume prediction for preoperative free flap volume planning remains difficult. The aim of this retrospective study was to determine the effect of various flap and patient factors on breast volume in the free-flap breast reconstruction setting. All female patients were included in the study group who underwent reconstruction using a latissimus dorsi flap or gluteal/lateral thigh flap between 2014 and 2021. Patient age and flap weight were compared to actual breast volume intraoperatively determined via a water displacement technique. Univariable and multilinear regression were performed to determine weight of the flap, patient age, and BMI along with the relationship between these variables and actual final volume of breast reconstruction. A total of 133 women met the criteria. On univariable analysis, weight of the flap (P < 0.01), patient age (P = 0.01), and BMI (P = 0.02) were significantly associated with actual breast volume determined intraoperatively. However, on multilinear regression analysis, there was no association between breast volume and flap weight, BMI, or age. Preoperative prediction of breast volume using flap weight may not be an accurate method of determining actual breast volume as it did not predict intraoperatively determined volume. In fact, the predictive formula for flap weight (2.316 + 0.036 × BMI) may not be able to predict the breast volume in a preoperative setting. The 8b isoform of the transient receptor potential channel-associated protein (TRIP8b) plays an essential role in the presynaptic regulation of serotonin (5-HT) neurotransmission, and 5-HT dysfunction contributes to numerous diseases, including anxiety and depression. Although expression of TRIP8b and the related genes 5-HT1AR and SERT are highly coexpressed throughout the brain, the regulation of SERT gene expression is still poorly understood. We propose that TRIP8b regulates the epigenetics of the SERT gene through DNA methylation. We analyzed TRIP8b, 5-HT1AR, SERT, and DNA methylation levels in the hippocampus and prefrontal cortex of TRIP8b knockout/knockout (KO/KO) mice and their age-matched wild-type (WT) littermates. The results indicated a decreased expression of TRIP8b, 5-HT1AR, and SERT in the hippocampus of KO/KO mice and that TRIP8b KO/KO mice had hypermethylation of the SERT promoter compared to WT mice. The results suggest that decreased TRIP8b expression promotes DNA hypermethylation and leads to inactivation of the SERT gene. We propose that the TRIP8b/DNA methylation/SERT/neurotransmitter pathway is critical for understanding the pathophysiology of 5-HT-related diseases, such as anxiety and depression. Therefore, there are several possible measures of sleep quality to choose from, each with their own advantages and disadvantages. One possible measure is the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index, which is a questionnaire that assesses seven components of sleep quality: subjective sleep quality, sleep latency, sleep duration, habitual sleep efficiency, sleep disturbances, use of sleeping medications, and daytime dysfunction. Another measure is the Epworth Sleepiness Scale, which is a self-report questionnaire that measures daytime sleepiness. The Sleep Disorders Questionnaire is another measure that is used to assess sleep-related problems. Finally, actigraphy is a device that can be used to measure sleep patterns based on motor activity. Choosing the appropriate measure for this outcome will depend on the study’s specific aims and goals. Diagnosis and Treatment of Chronic B‐Cell Lymphocytic Leukemia With Bone Marrow Involvement Mimicking Multiple Myeloma and Complicated by IgA‐λ Monoclonal Cryoglobulinemic Vasculitis: Response to Rituximab
&NA; We report a case of a 58‐year‐old woman who presented with multiple myeloma‐like cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. Her bone marrow biopsy and flow cytometry were found to be consistent with chronic B‐cell lymphocytic leukemia (B‐CLL), CD19 negative. The patient initially responded to corticosteroids and cyclophosphamide but had a progressive relapse and was successfully treated with rituximab. Our case illustrates the complexities of differential diagnosis between multiple myeloma and B‐CLL with bone marrow involvement mimicking multiple myeloma and the efficacy of rituximab in B‐CLL CD19 negative. .

Parenting is a complex task and can be challenging at times. Parents often feel stressed and worried about their abilities to raise their children, especially when navigating new parenting programs and interventions. As such, it is essential to understand parental stress and how it evolves after participating in a parenting program. This study provides new insights into the topic by evaluating changes in parental stress before and after participating in a parenting program. The results clearly show that participation in parenting programs can have a significant impact on reducing parental stress and improving well-being. These findings are particularly important for parents who may struggle with feelings of stress, anxiety, and uncertainty and for parents who are trying to adjust their parenting behaviors based on the latest research and recommendations. This study provides valuable insights for parents looking to improve their parenting skills and strategies and for those seeking guidance on how to provide their children with the best possible care. These insights are also valuable for researchers and clinicians seeking to understand how parenting programs can effectively support parents in raising their children. Overall, the results of this study demonstrate the importance of continued support and research around parenting programs and interventions. Jen Rational Design and Development of High‐Performance Carbon‐Based Filler for Polymeric Composites Toward Wearable Electronic Fiber The application of wearable electronic materials is becoming particularly prevalent in intelligent health monitoring and personal protective equipment due to their advantages of comfort, lightweight, stretchability, and safety. However, the traditional design and development of carbon black and carbon nanotubes (CB/CNT) are often associated with problems such as poor compatibility with polymers and poor uniform dispersion, which severely limit their performance and applications. In this work, the rational design strategy to construct a 3D nanoarchitecture framework in CB for wearable electronic devices is proposed using the “hard core/shell sandwiched soft nanoshell” structure. After surface modification by poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA), the CB/CNT/PVA composites with high specific surface area, three‐dimensional conductive networks, and excellent dispersion are obtained. This structure‐design strategy can be used to prepare wearable electronic fibers with good conductivity, which can be applied to wearable photocatalysis, capacitive wearable energy storage devices, and temperature sensors. Moreover, the electronic fiber has the potential to serve as personal protective equipment, such as high‐water‐retention clothing. This study provides a new platform for the development of a variety of carbon‐based functional wearable devices. Natural or synthetic polymers are being researched for over half a century to enhance the therapeutic efficacy of different chemotherapeutic agents. In this regard polyvinylalcohol (PVA) as a synthetic polymer has gained much interest due to its biocompatibility, biodegradability, and low cost. ## Internal validity
The effectiveness of an intervention depends upon its effectiveness in practice.  However, an evaluator who designs and implements an intervention might obtain results which are not the same as when it is used in practice. An intervention might not work well in practice because it is not implemented in the correct way.  When the implementation is effective, but the original intervention is not, this is known as "theory-practice gap".
Another phenomenon, commonly studied in internal validity, is the "female effect". This refers to the observation that if the observer of an experiment, or the participant of the experiment, is female; then the result may be less reliable than if the observer/participant were male. This is because women may be less tolerant of certain stimuli.
In practice, studies may have problems with their external validity in addition to, or instead of, their internal validity.

# Internal validity
In order to draw conclusions about cause and effect, it must be assumed that the study had enough internal validity. In an experiment, internal validity is achieved if the researcher is able to isolate the effect of the intervention from other uncontrolled variables that might influence the outcome. This isolation should be done such that the experimental group would achieve the same outcome if the intervention was not present (or could not be detected, in the case of placebo or non-conscious interventions). The control group of the experiment should be treated identically during the course of the experiment. These assumptions are known as the "independence assumption" or "stable unit assumption".
The process of improving a study so that it has a high internal validity is referred to as internal validity.
This process is accomplished first by making sure that the experimental design is the best that can be used for the study.
The two types of validity are very similar but are important for differing reasons:

The health of the US population has improved. The proportion of the population living over 65 years old increased from 3% in 1916 to 16% in 2015, and life expectancy at birth also increased, from 47.3 years in 1916 to 78.7 years in 2015. As a result, we have a larger population of patients who require chronic medications to prevent or treat disease. Despite these gains, the health system in the United States may be moving forward but still with blinders on as they travel in the same direction as our parents did 100 years ago. The US population now has a burden of chronic illness. Many of us have one or more chronic diseases that need management and, in particular, medications. Some of these diseases, such as heart disease and cancer, are the leading causes of death in the United States. Other diseases, such as diabetes and lung disorders, have life-altering consequences if uncontrolled. Furthermore, patients with chronic diseases face the risk of disabilities or premature death as a result of these diseases unless treated aggressively and consistently. Even if they can afford the medications and have insurance coverage, many still face barriers to accessing them. This issue of Clinical Therapeutics contains a number of papers focused on access to medications in the US and how we can improve the health of the population by eliminating barriers to accessing them. One very common gap is the patient’s inability or inaccessibility to fill prescriptions. In this issue, Rust and colleagues explore factors associated with barriers to filling prescriptions in the United States and provide strategies for addressing them. Other factors associated with barriers to filling prescriptions include race and ethnicity, age, and gender. Other articles in this issue examine disparities such as limited access to prescriptions for blacks compared with whites, older people compared with younger ones, and women compared with men

Two females from each cage were then killed at intervals of one week and the length of the oestrous cycle established. The females given a constant amount of food showed the longest oestrous cycle. With a gradual decrease in the amount of food given, from the start, the oestrous cycle became increasingly longer, especially to the females maintained at 30 degrees C. These rats also had lower urinary oestradiol concentrations. This effect seems to be due to a dietary reduction in energy. Background: Biomolecular pathways are a cornerstone for life, and the discovery of novel pathways has direct implications for understanding biological complexity and evolutionary diversity. Evaluating the number of unique pathways is an approach that helps to estimate the genetic makeup of organisms, shedding light on how they function under particular environments. Here, we explored the metabolic diversity in a major vertebrate model: Fugu rubripes. Results: The number of metabolic pathways with only known or unique F. rubripes genes is substantially greater than that for any other fish species. The tumor regression is evaluated with a combination of two measurements: change in tumor size from the baseline and percentage change in tumor size compared to baseline. If there is a reduction in tumor size compared to baseline, it is termed as RECIST response (partial response or complete response for more than a 30% size reduction), while no change compared to baseline is termed stables disease. - Noreply Influenza Vaccination in People Living with HIV-A Qualitative Study of Key Populations’ Perspectives
People living with HIV (PLHIV) in Sub-Saharan Africa are at increased risk of Influenza-associated disease. In this study, we explored barriers and drivers for vaccination in two key populations at increased risk of influenza-associated disease. A qualitative approach guided our conversations with sixteen bar- and gym-goers and eight taxi drivers recruited from five locations in Johannesburg. Key populations and stakeholders (N = 12) were interviewed and data analysis was guided by framework methodology. All stakeholders were concerned about influenza and its vaccine and encouraged PLHIV to vaccinate. A high self-perceived risk of influenza, limited knowledge about influenza and its vaccine and the perception that the vaccine could be harmful, were key barriers to vaccination for three main reasons. First, vaccines were associated with HIV medication and vaccination was considered to be harmful in that context. Second, vaccine recipients were associated with HIV and therefore perceived as being ill, unclean or a ‘sicko’. Third, the perceived risk or severity of influenza was low in comparison with other diseases. The barriers to vaccination may not be easily overcome; however, targeted interventions that address the three main themes, namely stigma and discrimination, trust and communication, may promote vaccine acceptance. 1 Carbachol and ipratropium bromide both produce strong neuromuscular blockade when present in the circulating blood in vivo, or when applied directly to the neuromuscular junction in vitro. The effects of single administration of low molecular weight (LMW) heparin on neurologic outcome after surgically induced ischemic stroke was investigated in 69 adult Wistar albino rats. Rats received heparin at the dose of 15 IU/kg 30 minutes before, or at the beginning of clamping, and at the onset of reperfusion of the middle cerebral (MCA) branch ipsilaterally. Control group of rats only had the MCA clamped. Neurofunctional evaluation was performed 6 hours and 72 hours after MCA occlusion/reperfusion. Rats were killed 72 hours after MCA occlusion and their brains were excised and processed for histological examination. Ischemia was successfully induced in the MCA of all 69 rats. A higher neurological score on the 6th and 72nd hour as compared with the onset of ischemia was found in rats which received heparin compared with the controls. Mortality in ischemic stroke animals was 23% in the study group and 24% in the controls (p > 0.050). No significant difference was found between the study group and the control group in brain ischemic changes which developed 72 hours after MCA clamping. We conclude that pre-procedural, and also after initiation of reperfusion, administration of low dose heparin, can be effective in reducing neurological impairment of animals undergoing surgically induced cerebral ischemia. .

You are a health sciences librarian in a state with a population of roughly 10 million people. Over the last several months, you have noticed an increase in the number of clinical research data collections in the ICPSR. You also notice that a small number of these data collections contain de-identified health information that are commonly accessed for secondary uses. These data sets are called restricted use data (see for some examples). What does restricted use data mean?
In this question, we will look at restricted use data:
What Does Restricted Use Data Look Like?

The Use of Ion Mobility Coupled with Mass Spectrometry to Evaluate the Binding Energies of Cd3d.
Ion mobility spectrometry combined with mass spectrometrics (IMS-MS) has emerged as a simple and informative method to assess protein binding. However, ion mobility coupled with mass spectrometric techniques require that charge states and collision cross section values be known. Although IMS-MS studies suggest charge state and collision cross section differences between protein complexes, the values are limited due to the lack of ion mobility and ion mobility collision cross section calibrants. Ion mobility experiments often report collision cross section values that are greater than 1100 A2 and are sometimes reported as absolute values. Here we propose that IMS charge and collision cross section assignment are more accurately assigned by reporting collision mobility and collision mobility cross section differences rather than absolute collision mobility cross section and collision mobility values. Using a method reported that assumes monoisotopic mass and does not account for hetero-charging we report that these differences are not in agreement for Cd3d (C2H2N6). While the assumption that only 0.1% of ions are hetero-charged improves the charge assignment agreement, Cd3d collision cross section differences are still not calculated accurately in the absence of a known gas-phase collision complex. Finally, reporting charge and collision cross section differences improves the accuracy of protein homodimer relative abundance estimation and is more consistent with other reports in the literature. The method is applicable to other biologically relevant homodimer and heterodimer complexes or other chemical complex

Great overview! The Effect of Antimicrobial Hand Washing Agents on Surgical Microbial Colonization
OBJECTIVE
 Antimicrobial hand wash has been introduced as an alternative to alcohol-based hand sanitizer for use in the healthcare setting. However, the potential for increased bacterial resistance has caused widespread controversy. The objective of our study was to evaluate the hypothesis that use of an antimicrobial hand wash with chlorhexidine gluconate (CHG) and triclosan (TRI) may result in increased colonization on the hands of surgical team members, leading to an increased risk of surgical site infection (SSI).


DESIGN
 Prospective study.


SETTING
 Large general community hospital.


PARTICIPANTS
 117 members of the surgical team in 3 surgical services, including surgeons, surgical nurses, surgical technicians, preoperative surgical assistants, anesthesiologists, and orthopaedic clinic physicians.


MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE(S)
 Surgical bacterial flora were cultured from the hands of the study participants. Changes between cultures taken immediately prior to wearing scrubs ("starting flora"), after use of a surgical scrub product ("scrubbed flora"), and after use of an antimicrobial hand wash product ("cleaned and dried flora") were analyzed.


RESULTS
 There was no significant increase in the level of organisms cultured on the hands of the study participants in any group. There was a significantly more positive culture after use of the antimicrobial hand wash (P = 0.004).


CONCLUSIONS
 Antimicrobial soap is a safe and effective method of decreasing preoperative bacterial flora in the scrubbed and dried state. Patients can be safe in assuming that, unlike alcohol-based hand sanitizers, no increase in resistant organisms will result from the use of antimicrobial soaps. That helps me get a better idea of how VAS measures pain. So, I know there can be interpersonal differences in interpretation that impact the VAS value, but what factors determine how patients mark on the scale?<s>In general, patients rate their level of pain intensity on a scale of 0 (no pain) to 10 (worst possible pain) by making a mark on a horizontal line. Pain patients typically rate pain as severe to excruciating. The distance from the no pain end of the scale to the rating that the patient selects is measured in cm to calculate the VAS value. A patient selects a number on the line that corresponds to the intensity of the pain experienced at that moment. There is usually a line labelled 0 (no pain) and 10 mm (worst imaginable pain) at each end of the line which is calibrated in 1 mm increments. Some VASs have a wider range of scoring, e.g. 0–100 or 100 mm. The VAS provides a measure of patients’ “pain severity.” However, this measure does not provide information about the location of pain or the cause of pain. .

Increased production of tumor necrosis factor-alpha contributes to the antinociceptive effect of morphine in capsaicin-injected rats.
Opiates are commonly used in the treatment of intractable pain. It is believed that opiates produce analgesia by decreasing the transmission of pain signals from primary afferent fibers to the central nervous system (CNS). Our aim is to evaluate a possible action of opiate system on tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-alpha, as an inflammatory modulator, and its possible involvement in the mechanism of analgesia produced by opiate system. In the present study, we investigated the effect of chronic opiate consumption on TNFalpha production in rats by measuring plasma and skin TNF-alpha levels as well as immunoreactivity of TNFalpha in dorsal root ganglion (DRG) neurons to demonstrate whether TNFalpha, whose production is modulated by opioid, may contribute to opiate-mediated effects on pain transmission. The animals were intrathecally administered with repeated doses of morphine or mu opioid receptors antagonist (I.C. Naloxone). The skin tissue and blood plasma were taken after injection of morphine to determine the changes in TNFalpha production. In addition, TNFalpha expression in rat DRG neurons was assessed by immunohistochemical techniques. We found that both intrathecal administration of morphine and blockade of mu opioid receptors inhibited TNFalpha level and immunoreactivity of TNFalpha-positive neurons in DRG neurons. Furthermore, the levels of plasma and skin TNFalpha were increased in morphine-injected or naloxone-treated rat, which is consistent with findings of increased TNFalpha in DRG neurons. These findings suggest that chronic opiate use decreases TNFalpha production, and that TNFalpha, produced by morphine, may contribute to the antinociceptive effect of opiates in the spinal inflammatory pain models. Our primary objectives included evaluating the long-term survival and AEs. The 5-year actuarial survival rates for stages III (n = 103) and IV (n = 143) patients were 46.3% ± 4.4% and 37.6% ± 4.0%, respectively, which were significantly lower than those for stage I (n = 74) and II (n = 86) patients (P < .001). Over a median follow-up of 28.4 months, only 10 patients (2.5%) with stage III, and 15 (12.7%) with stage IV disease developed cervical AEs. Although these patients had higher recurrence rates (71.1% vs 60.0%), local failure was the major cause of death in both stages (stage III: 74.4%, stage IV: 61.4%). We found that most cervical AEs were well tolerated. The actuarial 5-year rates of normal salivary and hypopharyngeal swallowing functions were 98.3 ± 2.9% (n = 12) and 99.9 ± 0.9% (n = 7) in stage III patients and 95.9 ± 2.4% (n = 9) and 100.0 ± 0.0% (n = 11) in stage IV patients. UNLABELLED
62Cu is an excellent PET-tracer for imaging many cancers with high Cu turnover. The uptake characteristics of 62Cu have to be optimized to obtain sufficient signal-to-noise ratio comparable to the clinical standard 18F-FDG, especially when using scanners with small detection systems or short scanning times that result in lower counts rates of decaying 62Cu-radiotracers. This study investigates the 18F-FDG-assisted 62Cu-imaging using two fully integrated positron-emission tomography (PET)/computed tomography (CT) systems (Biograph DUO, Siemens Healthcare) with the goal to provide a guideline for image acquisition and data analysis.


METHODS
Forty-five patients with suspected malignant pulmonary nodules and a reference patient without pathological findings underwent a 62Cu-PET/CT examination after the intravenous administration of 0.5 mg (140-200 MBq) of 62CuCl3. For 36 of these 46 patients an 18F-FDG-PET/CT as well as a 62Cu-PET/CT without 18F-FDG administration was performed. A time delay of 39.5 +/- 2.9 min between intravenous injection of 62CuCl and 18F-FDG occurred; a time delay of 74.7 +/- 19 min was necessary for 62Cu-PET/CT.


RESULTS
In 37 of 39 evaluable studies, increased activity in the location of pulmonary nodules could be found using 62Cu-enhanced CT, and 35 studies also using 62Cu PET. In all evaluable studies, the nodular hotspots were clearly distinguished from the surrounding lung parenchyma during 62Cu-enhanced CT.

MATERIAL AND METHODS

RESULTS

The Impact of a Novel Fiber Network on the Mechanical Properties of a Novel Resin Urethane Dressing.
OBJECTIVE
The aim of this study was to determine whether a novel elastic, non-adherent wound dressing consisting of an inner layer of a unique fiber network is able to provide sufficient support to withstand the strain and pressure generated by the use of a conventional compression device.


METHODS/DESIGN
Shear strain versus pressure data was obtained for a prototype dressing (Lyofoam) and two conventional dressings that were tested either in their unwrapped state or wrapped around a standardized test tube. Strain and pressure measurements were used to predict the shear stress acting on the wound bed surface with regard to the different dressing/device interactions (Lyofoam, Unna's boot and a soft crepe bandage) and the impact of these dressings on the compression of the tissue under the device.


RESULTS
Although the unwrapped prototype (Lyofoam) was susceptible to lateral movement with the use of a compression device, the prototype was still able to withstand the strain produced by the device. Moreover, it was determined that the strain applied to the wound, and therefore the wound pressure created by the compression device, depended primarily upon the compression device.


CONCLUSIONS
The study demonstrated that although the unwrapped Lyofoam dressing does require constant support to maintain a flat surface and is also susceptible to movement with the usage of a compression device, the prototype is able to withstand the strain, pressure, and friction generated by a compression device. In addition, the study indicated that the conventional dressings and devices

Fantastic! A Dichotomous Model of Aging

In this paper, we develop a dichotomous model of population aging. This model describes the joint dynamics of aging and mortality processes by taking into account the effects of social policies on these processes. In particular, we formulate a dichotomous compartmental model in order to study the impact of social policies of aging on public health. In particular, we analyze (i) the model dynamics of aging processes, (ii) the long-term effectiveness of these social policies to achieve a desired population aging, (iii) long-time aging dynamics for various initial conditions, and (iv) population and health measures. Finally, we show that the social policies of aging are long-time-scale efficient to increase the life expectancy of the population.

# Introduction
Population aging is a complex problem that affects every aspect of human lives. Indeed, the growing proportion of senior citizens is accompanied by a significant increase in global health care expenditures, especially in developed countries. In this manuscript, we develop a dichotomous model in order to analyze the population aging. Our starting point is the age-dynamics model, introduced by Oesterreicher and Katchalsky in their seminal paper. They established that with a certain type of assumptions, this age-structure model can be transformed into a population dynamics model by taking into account the immigration and death. Later, this dichotomous model was used by   Generalization of an exponential population model, Kaplan   to generalize Oesterreicher and Katchalsky's model to an age-period model.
The original age-stratified population models assume that the population dynamics is age-independent. Recently, some authors have introduced the time-dependent mortality and/or life expectancy as additive coefficients on the birth rate parameterized by age and time, respectively. The time dependent mortality and life expectancy as additive coefficients on the birth rate parameterized by the age and time have been studied, respectively by Kesterson and Mead. Note that the time dependence of the mortality and life expectancy is usually modeled by a multiplicative factor. In a multi-center randomized controlled trial patients in the lower PEEP + EIT group (5–6 cmH2O) showed a 9% improvement in oxygenation compared to control group, without any increased risks to the patients. However, EIT monitoring has not been previously shown to detect clinically relevant changes early on in patients with acute lung injury. The PFTs include PaO2, PaO2/FiO2, PEEP, airway resistance, and lung compliance. The EIT measurements are also performed. These two measurements are performed simultaneously (EIT and PFT). There is no change done to the ventilation settings. The primary end points are the correlation between the two measurement methods in terms of PaO2, PaO2/FIO2 ratio, PEEP, airway resistance, compliance and the accuracy of EIT algorithm. An open pilot study of the effect of coenzyme Q(10) therapy in pediatric patients with cancer-related fatigue.
CONTEXT
Cancer-related fatigue (CRF) is a debilitating component of cancer treatment. Numerous studies have evaluated pharmacologic modalities, but thus far, no single agent has been shown to reverse CRF.


OBJECTIVES
To determine whether coenzyme Q(10) (CoQ(10)) can alleviate CRF in pediatric patients, and in particular to determine the effect of CoQ(10) on the mitochondrial respiratory capacity.


DESIGN AND SETTING
This was an open pilot study evaluating the effect of CoQ(10) in 15 patients treated for solid malignant tumors with a mean age of 9.7 +/- 3.3 years.


INTERVENTIONS
In each patient, 100 mg/kg of CoQ(10) was administered BID for 4 weeks, followed by a 4-week rest period. This was followed by a 4-week trial of 200 mg/kg BID.


OUTCOME MEASURES
Cancer-related fatigue was measured using the pediatric versions of the Functional Living Index and the Pittsburgh Fatigue Scale. The mitochondrial respiratory capacity (maximal oxidation of succinate) was measured at the end of each stage.


RESULTS
Nine patients completed all three stages. Three refused additional treatment with CoQ(10), and the remaining three did not complete the second 2-week stage with CoQ(10) 200 mg/kg in the absence of toxicity. The effect of increasing concentrations of chlorine dioxide (ClO2 ) on the microflora in laboratory-distilled water, drinking water and a cold water distribution system was studied. In addition, the effectiveness of ClO2 in the elimination of viable micro-organisms from the cold water distribution system was tested. Distilled water, cold or tap water inoculated with pure strains of Gram-negative bacteria or Gram-positives (with and without a biofilm) were treated with various concentrations of ClO2 for 30 min. The number of viable cells of Gram-negative bacteria were determined using a plate count method for the biofilm bacteria and a most probable number (MPN) method for the free-living bacteria. The number of Enterobacteriaceae was determined using a Colilert-18 test. The cold water distribution system was treated with 3, 6 and 8 ppm ClO2 weekly and cultured at 3 and 8 h, and the results were compared. ClO2 concentrations above 6 ppm and for longer than 1 h inactivated the majority of the bacteria. No significant difference in performance was noted between the different concentrations of ClO2 . At all concentrations, the disinfectant was very effective against viable bacteria in the biofilm and also against the free-living bacteria present in the water system. The MPN/100 ml value in the ClO2 treated water after 30 min at 6 and 8 ppm was well below the guideline value for recreational waters, while the value in the drinking water was only slightly above the suggested value. .

Correlation of intracranial pressure level and duration with intracranial pressure prognosis in a neurological intensive care unit: A retrospective study
Objective: Intracranial pressure (ICP) can be estimated via bedside sonography, and its associated prognosis in patients with acute or chronic intracranial hypertension is closely related to the intracranial pressure value and duration for 5 days, 7 days, 14 days, 21 days, and 28 days. Methods: A retrospective study was conducted. Patients with acute or chronic intracranial hypertension were analysed, and their prognosis was evaluated according to the intracranial pressure level and duration. The outcome was neurologic death or deterioration, with the primary endpoint being ICP prognosis. The intracranial pressure level was determined to be good if ≤15 mmHg, moderate if 16–20 mmHg, and poor if ≥21 mmHg, and the intracranial pressure duration was judged to be good if its value for 5 days, 7 days, 14 days, 21 days, or 28 days was ≤5 mmHg, moderate if its value ranged between 6 and 10 mmHg, 11 and 15 mmHg, and 16 and 20 mmHg, and ≥21 mmHg, respectively. Results: In this study, it was found the intracranial pressure levels and duration for 5 days were independent risk factors that affected prognosis, and the intracranial pressure levels for 7 days, 14 days, 21 days, and 28 days were also independent risk factors that affected the prognosis; at the same time, the intracranial pressure duration value (OR = 1.95, 95% CI: 1.01, 3.74) and 14 days value (OR = 12.48, 95% CI: 0.16, 421.04) were independent risk factors that affected the prognosis; however, intracranial pressure levels for 14, 2

Introduction
Measuring the severity of hand eczema is a vital aspect of clinical trials assessing the efficacy of treatments, as it provides important information about the extent of skin damage and the impact of the condition on patients’ quality of life. Hand eczema is a skin condition that affects the hands and can cause severe irritation and soreness. It can have a major impact on daily life, making it important to assess the severity of the condition accurately.
What is hand eczema?
Hand eczema, also known as hand dermatitis, is a skin condition that affects areas of the skin on the hands. It can be caused by various irritants, allergens, and contact with harmful substances that irritate the skin. Symptoms of hand eczema may include burning, itching, redness, cracking, scale, dryness, and bleeding. The severity of the symptoms can vary depending on the individual.
The condition can be mild, moderate, or severe. Mild hand eczema symptoms will likely include itching while moderate-to-severe symptoms may include inflammation of the skin, pain, and cracked or bleeding fingertips.
In this article, we will discuss the severity assessment of hand eczema as a primary outcome measure.
Assessing the severity of hand eczema
There are various ways to assess the severity of hand eczema, but the most common method is based on the degree of erythema, scaling, and oozing. This approach is designed to give a general overview of the symptoms and help guide treatment decisions. If the severity of the hand eczema is mild, it may be appropriate to start with a topical steroid, as this can improve the symptoms within a few days. However, if the symptoms are moderated severe, it may be necessary to initiate treatment with an oral antihistamine prescription or systemic immunosuppressive agents, in addition to the topical steroid.
There are other ways to assess the severity of hand eczema such as the Eczema Area and Severity Index (EASI) and the Hand Eczema Severity Index

NifV is a protein, encoded by the nifV gene, found in free form in azotobacters. Overproduced NifV, when added to a wild type cell extract in the absence of a membrane preparation, stabilizes proteins that bind 2-oxoacid dehydrogenase complex E2 components or a precursor of the enzyme (Gan et al. (1992) Biochim. Biophy Acta 1186, 39-54). NifV is also an activator of the NifX protein. NifV is not required for nif gene expression or for activity of nitrogenase in vivo but it is required for maximally high levels of NifH expression, for proper assembly of maturation factors NifQ through NifEN, and for proper assembly of the large subunit, the Fe protein. We previously suggested that NifV is probably necessary for optimal activity of a membrane-bound dehydrogenase(s) that, via a redox reaction, reduces the E-to-Z transition of the Fe protein (Gan et al. 1992). In this paper we show that the activity of this enzyme is inhibited reversibly by an inhibitor in nifV mutant extracts. Our work suggests that NifV influences Fe protein assembly by regulating intracellular redox status. # Recommendations
For people with pemphigus with non-fulminant moderate or severe disease that is difficult to control with current first-line treatments:
Offer rituximab, which may increase remission and decrease the risk of recurrence compared with intravenous immunoglobulins.
For people with pemphigus who do not respond to other second-line therapies, or who are intolerant of them:
Consider intravenous immunoglobulins, taking into account their lower effectiveness in remission induction than rituximab. Also take into account how people would want to be managed: this includes their preference for a non-surgical procedure and whether they live near a suitable transfusion centre. In doing so, take into account the cost effectiveness of each drug and whether treatment should be offered alongside best supportive care.# The technology
Rituximab (MabThera) and intravenous immunoglobulins (IGIVs) are immunomodulatory therapies for pemphigus. Rituximab and IGIVs are licensed in the UK for use in diseases characterised by B‑ and T‑cell proliferation (including chronic lymphocytic leukaemia, hairy cell leukaemia, non‑Hodgkin's lymphoma, multiple myeloma, immune thrombocytopenia and pemphigus vulgaris) and for antibody deficient patients with recurrent infections.
For more details on rituximab, see the summary of product characteristics (SPC; MabThera).
For more details on IGIVs, see the SPC (Octagam).
Rituximab is available as a concentrate. Dose: 375 milligr

MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are an important class of post‐transcriptional regulators of gene expression, but they have long had unclear roles in transcriptional regulation. Here, we explored how miRNA‐mRNA binding contributes to direct transcriptional regulation using an affinity‐based RNA purification protocol, Deep Analysis of RNA by Target Selection (DARTS). Our results indicate that miRNA‐mRNA binding is associated, but not exclusively required to mediate, gene expression. We found that mature miR‐122 and miR‐33a‐3p bind directly to overlapping transcript targets, including mRNAs involved in the regulation of cholesterol/fatty acid metabolism. The binding of mature miR‐122 to its targets was consistent with predicted secondary structures that promoted base pairing to these transcripts. Further, mature miR‐122 bound and regulated gene expression even in the absence of AGO2. DARTS results suggest that mature miRNA binding is a mechanism for the transcriptional regulation of targets associated with lipid metabolism but is not exclusively required to mediate changes in gene expression. Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is an endocrine disorder that is caused by a genetic predisposition or multistep interactions of genetic and environmental factors. Phospholipase C/inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate pathway (PLC/IP3) is involved in insulin signaling and G-protein-mediated Ca(2+) mobilization, and both are involved in the pathophysiology of PCOS.


OBJECTIVE
This work aimed to evaluate whether the PLC-related inositol-5-phosphatase (PIF) gene is associated with susceptibility to PCOS in women from Northern India.


DESIGN
Case patients (n = 209) were identified as having PCOS on the basis of clinical, anthropometric, and hormonal parameters. Control women (n = 200) were recruited by using stringent criteria for exclusion of patients with hyperandrogenism. Cases were subcategorized on the basis of the homeostasis model of assessment index and hyperandrogenism into PCOS with ovulatory disorder (n = 125) and nonovulatory PCOS (n = 84).


RESULTS
A single nucleotide polymorphism of PIF (rs8045682) has significant association in the whole pooled data (Pc = 0.024, odds ratio = 0.60, 95% confidence intervals 0.40-0.88), which was also noticed (1) in the subjects with nonovulatory PCOS (Pc.02, odds ratio = 0.47, 95% confidence intervals 0.26-0.89), and (2) with overweight/obese status (Pc.03, odds ratio = 0.61, 95% confidence intervals 0.37-0.874).

MRI is the gold standard for imaging microspheres in clinical practice, but in preclinical studies, a CT scan is more common and practical

CT (computed tomography) and MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) are used to assess the accuracy of implantation, which is closely related to the amount of the therapeutic agent in the tumor area.

Even though MRI is able to offer high-resolution multi-directional isotropic images, it is not easily available in a preclinical setting. So it is usually not used in preclinical studies.

On the other hand, it is more practical to use CT to assess the injection process, because a CT scan is available in most preclinical settings. Also, CT imaging provides information on the injection, including the location and amount of the therapeutic agent, while MRI imaging only provides the information on the localization of the microspheres without estimating the distribution or amount.

These considerations imply that in preclinical studies evaluating the treatment of liver cancer by transarterial embolization, MRI imaging is not the first choice of modality and CT imaging is frequently used instead. In contrast, in clinical trials, MRI is commonly used in the assessment of the microspheres when they are applied for lung and bone cancer …

Although MRI seems to be the first choice in clinical practice, CT scans are equally applicable when microsphere injection in a preclinical setting is assessed.

Nursing and the quality of dying.
The quality of dying in the United Kingdom needs to be examined by nurses if the goals of nursing are to be achieved, as these goals will only achieve their full potential when the concept of quality of dying is incorporated into the holistic nursing process. The primary purpose of this article is to re-examine the goals of nursing with the view to assessing their relevance to the care of the dying and to determine where, if any, the concept of quality of dying could be incorporated into current nursing practice. Immunophenotype and Clinical Characteristics of Leukocytes in Patients with Nephrotic Syndrome

Background: It has been reported that nephrotic syndrome (NS) patients show a decrease in blood lymphocyte count, increase in neutrophil count, and decrease in neutrophil/lymphocyte ratio. We hypothesized that there might be a difference in the phenotype and function of blood cells at the onset of NS and that leukocyte changes would indicate the activity of the disease or patient status. Methods: This was a prospective observational study. To the Editor. —In the article, "Anorexic Weight Loss," 1 the authors refer to the "obscene weight of today's patient." I would like to point out that the "obscenity" does not lie in the weight but rather in the psychology of the person. I doubt that, as a society, we can be too thin. Transesophageal echocardiography during the anesthetic management of a neonate with pulmonary hypertension.
An infant with pulmonary hypertension who was scheduled for cardiac catheterization and balloon dilation of the right ventricle is described. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) revealed severely thickened pulmonary artery and valve, which suggested the possibility of pulmonary artery dissection. Cardiac catheterization did not show a major anomaly other than severe pulmonary hypertension. Balloon dilation of the right ventricle was performed and cardiopulmonary bypass with left heart venting could be performed without any complications. TEE was also helpful in detection of residual intracardiac or peripheral emboli. We conclude that TEE was a valuable technique for the anesthetic management of this infant with pulmonary hypertension. .

METHODS
All patients presented with either a benign neoplasm, epitheloid neoplasm of uncertain malignant potential (ENUMP) or GI stromal tumors between 0.5 and 2 cm in size. Significance Fluid-rocks interactions in the Earth’s lower crust and upper mantle can affect the chemical and isotopic evolution of rocks by introducing elements and isotopes from subducting materials, such as water, carbonate dissolution products, and melt into the crust and mantle. Our work provides constraints on the composition of such fluids with important implications for carbon and nitrogen cycling. The presence of water and carbonate-rich fluids in the upper mantle is a long-standing debate, which until now has been poorly constrained because only hydroxides are stable at ambient pressure and temperature above ∼2.5 GPa. The discovery of europium and BaO and the isotopic variations of these minerals within subduction and mid-ocean ridge basalt xenoliths reveals the presence of fluids in the top of the mantle. Fluid-rock interactions in the Earth’s lower crust and upper mantle can affect the chemical and isotopic evolution of rocks by introducing elements and isotopes from subducted materials into the crust and upper mantle. Using microanalytical techniques, we report major, minor, and trace element compositions for strontium, europium, and barium oxides in several granulite xenoliths as a function of depth. We show that SrO, EuO, and BaO in mantle rocks, as well as in the most heavily metamorphosed granulite xenoliths, are isotopically heavy relative to their respective crustal equivalents. One important aspect is the psychological wellbeing of the caregivers. It is crucial to evaluate their mental health and emotional wellbeing as they play a vital role in providing care to family members and friends. Assessing the subjective happiness and life satisfaction of the caregivers using measures such as the Oxford Happiness Questionnaire, the Life Satisfaction Scale, and the Subjective Happiness Scale. Another aspect to look into is the physical health of the caregivers, as providing care to someone requires physical effort and can lead to physical health issues. Consider using physical health-related questionnaires such as the Short Form-36 (SF-36) Health Survey, the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI), and the Brief Pain Inventory (BPI) to track the physical health status of the caregivers. Evaluating the quality of life (QOL) of caregivers is essential. Questionnaires like the World Health Organization’s QOL BREF or the Quality of Life Enjoyment and Satisfaction Questionnaire-Short Form (Q-LES-Q-SF) could be administered to assess the overall QOL of the caregivers. In addition, considering measures like the World Health Organization’s Disability Assessment Schedule (WHODAS) or the Caregiver Assessment of Caregiver Activity Time (CATCH) would be helpful in gauging the degree of difficulty in performing daily tasks. The Caregiver Readiness to Change Scale (CRRS), the Family Adaptability and Cohesion Scale (FACES-IV), and the Conflict Tactics Scale (CTS) could be administered to assess the degree of readiness and family cohesion for care. It is crucial to consider factors such as physical, psychological, and social well-being, QOL, difficulties performing daily tasks, readiness, and family cohesion for care. Measuring the effectiveness of the ACT-CSP program using the above-mentioned measures would provide reliable and comprehensive insights into the caregivers’ well-being and overall experience providing care. In patients with critical illness, inadequate caloric or protein intake may compromise recovery. This in turn may predispose to adverse long-term medical outcomes, particularly when the period of nutritional insufficiency exceeds a few days. The optimal feeding method for the critically ill patient remains controversial and is the subject of ongoing research studies. However, it is important to understand the physiologic alterations associated with acute illness and the resultant changes in nutritional needs. This review will focus on critical care nutrition, with specific emphasis on: i) changes in basal metabolism associated with critical illness; ii) nutritional requirements during critical illness; and iii) the management of enteral and parenteral nutrition in the critically ill patient. A Novel and Safe Strategy for Cardioversion and Permanent His Bundle Pacing in the Same Setting

Objective: This report describes a novel technique for cardioversion and His bundle pacing (HBP) in the same setting which was carried out after placement of an electrode catheter in the right ventricular outflow tract (RVOT) to ensure an effective retrograde His bundle activation.Case Synopsis: HBP was performed after coronary sinus catheter positioning in a 70-year-old male patient. In the same setting, the RVOT catheter was inserted to perform ventricular cardioversion. In both procedures, effective His bundle activation was ensured and the electrocardiogram showed evidence of HBP. The procedure was well-tolerated and all the catheters and the sheaths were easily withdrawn. After the procedure, the patient was discharged 3 days later. At one-month follow-up, the patient was asymptomatic and in sinus rhythm.Conclusion: This case report confirms the feasibility of this simple technique which is associated with low invasiveness and no additional risks for the patient. It is useful for pacing-dependent patients with cardiac rhythm disorders and bradycardia.

Materials with noncentrosymmetric (NCS) crystal structures offer a fascinating playground for the development of functional functional materials with nonlinear optical properties, ferroelectricity, multiferroicity, and magnetism. However, the design of NCS materials is challenging, especially for polycrystalline compounds. In this work, based on topological considerations, we design an NCS metal-organic framework by combining the advantages of the two-dimensional (2D) structure and the metal-organic framework. A series of NCS Zn-MOFs were synthesized by the solvothermal reaction of zinc hydroxide acetate and 3,6,9,12,15,18-hexaiminocarbazolyl, and further structural refinements have been conducted based on the single-crystal structure determination analysis. These NCS MOFs exhibit highly anisotropic charge transport and intrinsic semiconductivity, accompanied by a photocurrent onset lower than 300 nm. Meanwhile, they can be easily fabricated into microelectrodes and have a promising potential for electrochromism. Density functional theory calculations and spectroscopic measurements reveal that the strong electron-electron correlations play a critical role in the electrical property tuning. This work provides new insights into the potentialities and design principles of the family of NCS MOFs with 2D structures. Effect of Different Pretreatments on the Bioactive Compounds of Açaí (Euterpe oleracea Mart.)

This study aimed to assess the effect of different pretreatments on the bioactive compounds of açaí. Three pretreatments (control, washed, and dried) were applied to samples of Euterpe oleracea Mart., submitted to the extraction of bioactive compounds, using different solvents for extraction. Total polyphenolic compound contents in the extracts increased when the açaí was washed, with the highest increase in the control sample (36.36%). Polyphenolic compounds obtained after the extraction of samples washed improved to a lesser extent, and there was no significant difference in the polyphenolic content of the dried sample before and after extraction of bioactive compounds, compared to the control and washed samples. Considering the preconcentration of bioactive compounds of E. oleracea samples, there was no significant effect of pretreatments, except for washing, which caused a slight increase in the content of polyphenols extracted in these samples. The total content of flavonoids was highest in extractions containing hydroalcoholic mixtures and the highest result was 22.77 mg/g in the dried sample, whereas the lowest was observed in extractions with absolute ethanol (17.31 mg/g of dried açaí) and occurred mainly in the control samples. The highest flavonoids content is found in açaí samples.

~Hunter Impact of N-acetyl-cysteine on lung functions in patients of bronchial asthma. Objectives: There is an increase in airway neutrophilia in patients with severe bronchial asthma. Neutrophil activation has been shown to release a range of molecules that promote injury and inflammation including superoxide, oxygen radicals, myeloperoxidase, leukotrienes. Ozonolysis produces toxic reactive aldehydes such as malondialdehyde (MDA) and 4 hydroxynonanal (4 HNA), which can cause severe oxidative damage. Therefore, preventing the formation of reactive aldehydes should afford protection against lung injury. The objective of this study is to study the effect of N-acetyl-cysteine (NAC) on lung functions and airway inflammation in severe asthmatic patients.Methods: In a randomized study, 70 patients were randomized to receive 400 mg NAC BID orally for 12 weeks along with standard therapy. Patients were assessed clinically for bronchial asthma (BA) severity, and also had blood for total serum immunoglobulin E (IgE), lipid peroxidation (malondialdehyde [MDA]) and airway neutrophil count; the latter was estimated using bronchioalveolar lavage (BAL).Results: NAC significantly reversed the severity of BA compared to the control patients whose status remained unchanged. The levels of MDA decreased significantly on NAC therapy in severe asthmatics versus controls. NAC also significantly decreased airway neutrophilia in severe asthmatics.Conclusions: This study revealed that NAC is effective in decreasing the airway neutrophilia and serum MDA levels which indicates its role in improving lung functions in severe asthmatics along with standard therapy. # Introduction Asthma is a chronic respiratory inflammatory

Effects of inhibition by verapamil and N‐acetyl cysteine of acetaminophen‐induced hepatotoxicity in mice
The protective effects of verapamil and N‐acetyl cysteine (NAC) on acetaminophen‐induced hepatotoxicity were investigated in mice. Male ICR mice were divided into four groups, a control group, an acetaminophen‐treated group and a verapamil‐ or NAC‐treated group. The acetaminophen‐treated group was given an acetaminophen dose of 150 mg/kg orally and the other three groups were given the same volume of normal saline as the vehicle. Verapamil and acetaminophen were administered orally at a dose of 50 mg/kg and 150 mg/kg for 2 h, respectively. NAC and acetaminophen were dosed intraperitoneally as a solution in 0.1 M HCl (100 mg/kg) and orally as a suspension in normal saline (50 mg/kg) for 2 and 4 h, respectively. At 48 h, the blood was collected by cardiac puncture, and the liver was excised for measurement of liver weights and serum transaminase concentrations. In all acetaminophen‐treated groups, increased serum activities of alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and increased liver weights were observed. Verapamil significantly decreased the mean serum ALT and AST activities by 52.8 ± 8.9% and 48.4 ± 11.7%, respectively. Verapamil also significantly inhibited the increases in liver weight. The group pretreated with NAC showed no significant differences compared with the acetaminophen group. In this study, only verapamil protected mice against acetaminophen‐induced toxicity. The results suggest that verapamil may inhibit the toxicity of acetaminophen by preventing the leakage of aspartate aminotransferase

Background: Human hantavirus (HV) infections are one of the public health problems in China, but only a few studies on the epidemiology of human HV infection have been carried out. In the present study, we estimated the seroprevalence of HV using a commercial enzyme linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) kit in five cities of China.Methodology/Principal Findings: A total of 350 serum samples collected between 2010 and 2011 from different population groups including farmers, students, soldiers, and urban workers in five cities in China were tested for anti-HV antibodies using a commercial ELISA kit, as well as a laboratory-made competitive ELISA to identify the causative HV. According to the commercial kit, 17 samples (4.86%) from two cities tested positive. These were from three farmers, one soldier, and nine students. From the same samples, 7 samples (2.00%) were positive by the laboratory-made competitive ELISA, from which 1 was from a farmer, 2 from soldiers, and 4 from students. All the ELISA-positive samples were negative by immunofluorescence serological assay, indicating that these were false positive results. No samples were positive by a microneutralization assay.Conclusions: Our results revealed a high prevalence of IgG and low titre antibodies against HV in people from five cities in China. Increased HV studies, including active field investigations are needed to confirm the diagnosis and to estimate the real seroprevalence of HV in China.

Awesome! I'm glad we're making great progress. Now, let's turn our attention to the analysis plan. Phenotypes of mucopolysaccharidosis
Mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS) encompass a subset of rare, progressive, inherited lysosomal storage disorders that result from the inability of cells to degrade glycosaminoglycans (GAGs). Currently, 11 subtypes of MPS are known. The broad array of clinical symptoms found in MPS is attributed to the heterogeneous nature of cellular GAG content. GAGs vary greatly in size; some (e.g. dermatan sulfate) are only slightly larger than most proteins, while others (e.g. polyglucosan type IV) are over 1 million times larger. In addition, GAG size varies greatly in terms of both monomeric repeating units and degree of substitution with sulfate or hexuronic acid. Because the size of mucopolysaccharides (along with their localization) determines phenotype, the phenotypic consequences of GAG accumulation are unique in each MPS type. Clinically, MPS disorders are grouped into three main syndromes: attenuated (Hurler syndrome/MPS IH; Scheie syndrome/MPS IH-SH; Hurler-Scheie syndrome/MPS IS), intermediate (MPS II, III and V-VI) and severe (MPS IVA, B, C, D and VII). Accumulation of excessive GAGs is pathognomonic of MPS; therefore, analysis of urinary or plasma GAG profiles is used as a method to diagnose MPS. This review focuses on the phenotypes of MPS, and describes the molecular basis of GAG deposition and the underlying mechanisms for MPS.
