model_response: We agree that this outcome is directly related to the efficacy of luspatercept in reducing the need for blood transfusions. However, we believe that measuring this outcome alone will not provide a complete picture of the impact of luspatercept on study participants and the broader patient population. This is because patients still require blood transfusions even after receiving luspatercept. Therefore, measuring the number of units of blood transfused would underestimate the benefit of luspatercept in that it would ignore the potential reduction in the number and frequency of transfusion-related complications associated with a decrease in the number of transfusions. To address this issue, we propose to supplement the existing outcome measure with two additional outcomes that assess the impact of luspatercept on specific transfusion-related complications and patient-reported outcomes. These outcomes include the number of days spent in the hospital and the number of days with severe pain associated with transfusions. In addition, we suggest assessing the quality of life by measuring the number of transfusion-related complications and the severity of pain associated with transfusions. These additional outcomes will provide a more comprehensive picture of the impact of luspatercept on patients and the broader patient population. Furthermore, we propose to assess the reduction in transfusion requirements after receiving luspatercept by using a repeated-measures approach to examine changes over time. This will provide a more real-time assessment of the impact that luspatercept has on transfusion requirements and other measures. To improve the design of the questionnaire, we propose incorporating an additional qualitative outcome assessment through an interview. This will help gather more information on the factors that may affect response to luspatercept. It will also allow the study team to better understand patients’ responses. By doing so, we will be able to improve the treatment and care of patients with this condition. Please provide your valuable feedback on the suggested changes.<s>

Since ancient times, it can be seen that various countries have been trying to find ways of improving the health of people, and to prevent disease and ensure health in a more scientific and comprehensive manner. In recent years, with the rapid development of medical science, the traditional concept of health has been replaced by the concept of new health, which is based on the physiological integrity theory of organism. Health promotion behavior is a comprehensive behavioral measure targeted at specific risk factors in order to achieve the goal of health education, which means to promote health and prevent diseases by changing people's behavior patterns. Therefore, this paper introduces the definition of health promotion behavior, and points out that promoting health requires not only improving the scientific level of medical technology and diagnosis and treatment, but also paying attention to the behavior of people's own health. The development of biochemical markers in blood compatible materials: a review.
This paper reviews the development of research in biochemical markers with an emphasis on their use in materials for blood compatibility. There are many biochemical markers of thrombus formation and its reversal including platelet activation, coagulation activation, fibrinolysis and complement activation. This review examines the role of the different markers in the determination of the blood compatibility of materials. Different analytical methods are reported, and the pros and cons of using these methods analysed. Blood compatible materials can be developed by modifying their surface properties and it is possible to modulate surface properties via coating and by immobilisation of polymers on non-biomaterial surfaces. The effect of coating with polymeric layers on the blood compatibility is also examined, with the goal to produce polymers that are biocompatible, are biologically inert, are able to resist the generation of platelet thrombi and are able to activate fibrinolysis. That sounds comprehensive. Thank you. Assessment of antibacterial potential and chemical profile of two endophytic fungi against phytopathogens

Among endophytic fungi, Colletotrichum lentis and Paecilomyces formosus, isolated from lentils and cereals, respectively, have been extensively studied as biopesticides to protect crops from phytopathogens. To achieve a complete understanding about the chemical profile and antibacterial activity of those endophytic fungi against pathogens, the culture filtrate derived from C. lentis and P. formosus and some of its metabolites were evaluated for antibacterial potential at concentrations varying from 5 mg L −1 to 100 mg L −1 respectively. The active fraction obtained from C. lentis was identified through GC-MS analysis as maltol and cis-11octadecenoic acid ethyl ester [1,2-dipalmitoylglycerol (DPG)]. The biochemical analysis indicated that some of the tested endophytic fungi and active metabolites were able to inhibit the growth of pathogenic bacteria, and the activity was higher for C. lentis than P. formosus metabolites. The DPG was considered the best inhibitor with the highest activity (89.00 ± 1.01, 80.75 ± 1.30 to 68.25 ± 0.74 against Xanthomonas campestris pv. campestris, Erwinia carotovora, and Agrobacterium tumefaciens, respectively). C. lentis produced mainly (1)-usambarolide F, and some of the metabolites were identified such as (7S,8R)-epoxy-7methyl-6-deoxypestheicid, asperlicin, and citrinin. C. lentis showed a significantly (P < 0.05) higher antibacterial activity than P. formosus, particularly for X. campestris pv. campestris, E. carotovora, and Salmonella Enteritidis.

Good question. The gait speed will be assessed at the beginning of the training and every month of use. When assessing the 10MWT, patients will be instructed to walk over a flat surface and to cover the required distance as quickly as possible. The research team will record the time needed to complete the test. The 10MWT was selected because it provides the most valid and reliable assessment of walking speed in PD. The second secondary outcome measure is the “Timed Up and Go Test (TUGT).” This test asks patients to rise from a chair, walk at a fixed pace of 3 meters, turn, walk back, and sit back down. It assesses mobility and balance in daily life activities. As with the 10MWT, the time from standing to sitting will be recorded. Research has confirmed the validity of this measure. The third outcome measure is the “10-second Chair Stand Test (10CST).” This quick and easy test looks at one’s lower body strength and physical function. In the test, patients can be instructed to stand (or perform a seated to stand) movement whenever they hear a signal, and try to use two hands to hold the handrails (or no handrails). The number of repetitions completed within 10 sec is the score. If a participant completes any part of the chair stand movement and has to sit down, the test is stopped and the number of repetitions they completed is recorded. The clinical feasibility of this test has been proven by others. Lastly, the outcome measure is “Activity of Daily Living (ADL) scale (ADLS).” This questionnaire assesses patients’ function by evaluating their day-to-day abilities. Specifically, the ADLS looks at a patient’s ability to perform ADL, such as dressing, bathing, eating, and transferring. The ADLS measures the patients’ mobility and ability to conduct activities of daily life. A few research teams have validated the use of the ADLS. Taken together, the research team will evaluate each patient’s gait speed, strength, and ADL at the beginning of each study and once monthly during the study. The other secondary outcome measures are as follows:
Falls efficacy-the Falls Efficacy Scale measures how afraid a person is of falling during specific activities. This tool is used to evaluate the effectiveness of a program.
Activities of Daily Living: The Barthel Index assesses a patient's ability to perform essential tasks such as dressing and bathing on a 100-point scale. This scale measures a patient's independence and provides an overall assessment of their recovery.
Quality of Life: The SF-12 is a quality-of-life measure which is used to assess the physical and mental wellbeing of a person. It includes questions on overall health, physical functioning, and mental health.
Balance: The Berg Balance Scale assesses a person's stability and ability to maintain a standing position. It includes 14 items and scores range from 0 (poor balance) to 56 (good balance).
Gait analysis: Gait analysis is a tool used to measure gait parameters and evaluate changes in walking patterns over time. It measures foot strikes, stance, and swing, and also provides feedback on step length and duration.
Rehabilitation efficiency: This is a score given by the clinical team to evaluate the outcome of the rehabilitation program.
The secondary outcome measurements evaluate the improvement in the overall health and well-being of the patient after receiving the Ekso therapy. These measures assist in determining the success of a program and provide valuable insight into how well patients are progressing.

Two cases of recurrence following a successful closure of postinfarction ventricular septal defect were reported. Both of the cases were treated successfully with surgery. The postinfarction ventricular septal defect was closed again with a pericardium patch. Both patients are alive at the 3rd month and 1st year and 2nd months after the 2nd operation. ## Conclusion: social networking is here to stay
Many of us are not yet comfortable engaging with this newer mode of communication with an expectation that we would also need to learn the nuances of the social networking world. It is a rapidly evolving medium with the potential to bring our research closer to the people with a global reach. Thus it is only a matter of time before a social media platform becomes instrumental in bringing together the scientific discourse and the global scientific community. There is also a potential for social media platforms to transform the world of academic research. Involvement with online journals, conferences, and other scientific discourse can ensure quicker access to a particular research. As such an online mode of academic discourse allows for a broader, faster, and more interactive communication between colleagues in different parts of the world; at the same time, the accessibility of information to the public is also facilitated via social media platforms. A very good example of this has been the evolution of Cochrane Collaboration   The Cochrane Collaboration: improving health care worldwide, Young   and EBROH [8] electronic journals, and the use of social networking media for online conferences, both of which have enabled a lot more scientific discourse over the past two decades.

# Introduction
Fertility, and especially the sterile seed production, is one of the most important traits in production of oilseed crops. Fertility indicates the ratio of seed production per plant and the main factors affecting this trait are genetic, environmental, and agricultural practices. Oilseed canola (Brassica napus L.) is one of the important oilseed crops grown in China, which is also one of the main sources for edible oil. The high seed yield of canola is essential for its global production. To obtain more canola seeds per plant at harvest, plant density is one of the important factors to be considered since plant density directly affects the final yield and seed production in oilseed crops. However, there is a limit to how high the plant density can go that affects seed yield and oil concentration and also affects oilseed crop fertility.
Maintaining seed fertility is dependent of the quantity and quality of seed nutrients. Seed nutrients, such as carbohydrates, lipids, and proteins, are considered key elements in determining nutritional quality and quantity of seeds and their capacity to maintain the plant's ability to grow and develop . Seed nutrient is one of the important indicators for evaluating seed quality and germination. Carbohydrates and lipids are required for providing energy, while protein is the substrate for various processes, including seed germination and seedling growth.
Seed density has been extensively studied in oilseed crops, including oilseed rape. Many researchers have attempted to optimize oilseed crop seed density, and the ideal oilseed crop seed density is still unknown . Previous studies have shown that higher seed density can increase the seed weight of plants. However, it also increases the self-shading phenomenon, which may lead to a decrease of seed weight . There are few papers on the influence of seeding rate or population density on canola seed quantity, which may be influenced by the number of seeds per fruiting. When measuring blood pressure, patients should measure each arm without food, alcohol, caffeine, or exercise for at least 30 minutes before taking blood pressure. # Abstract Background
Background This study aims to develop a decision aid app for humeral shaft fractures by using the Health Belief Model through the qualitative interview approach. It is expected that the patients can have knowledge and awareness about their disability and they will have the opportunity to express their concerns.

## Objective
A decision aid for humeral shaft fractures to assist patients in making the right health decisions, both in terms of timing and methods of treatment so that the results can be better, and to provide accurate information, which can encourage patients to participate actively in the decision-making process, resulting in patients being better prepared, making informed decisions, and having greater self-confidence in health issues.

# Methods
The research carried out was a qualitative study that used interviews with open and followup questions, which was conducted through an in-depth interview in several sessions. All data were transcribed and grouped into themes consisting of attitude, health belief, decision aid, and patient profile based on the Health Belief Model then was analyzed through content analysis.

# Result
Based on the results of the study, it can be concluded that a valid and reliable decision aid can be developed using the health belief model approach and the data obtained from the interviews with the participants in the decision aid development for humeral shaft fractures application.

## Conclusion
Decision about the method of treatment is based on the patient's knowledge and attitude towards treatment and information about the condition. A decision aid may be beneficial because it may change a patient. A decision aid will be developed to assist in providing information and the impact of humeral shaft fracture decision support to patients based on the Health Belief Model information in a form suitable for patients' level of understanding and based on their needs.

High throughput microfluidic-fabricated electrophysiology: electrokinetic focusing to accelerate cellular analysis.
Electrophysiology analysis is an electrically based technique in which current is used to measure the membrane potential of a cell while it experiences a variety of electrical signals. In addition to its useful functions in diagnosis, electrophysiology analysis has provided valuable information about the biological, pharmaceutical, and drug-delivery aspects of many pathological conditions. Conventional electrophysiology tools often contain complex cell-culture environments that hinder the collection of meaningful data. This limitation can be overcome through the development of high throughput systems that allow the rapid collection of cellular information. Here we describe an electrophysiology device that has recently been fabricated by photolithographic techniques. This process used a photomask to create inexpensive arrays of micro-electrodes using standard microchip fabrication materials. The array of electrodes includes multiple recording electrodes (nine-channel array) and multiple reference electrodes (three-channel array). The array of electrodes was connected to either a cell-culture chamber or a drug reservoir, permitting the automated delivery of drugs to cells. The drug-delivery system is connected to a pumping mechanism and a microfluidic channel, which allows cells to accumulate around individual recording electrodes. This device has a cell-culture chamber that contains high-density arrays of cells at a fixed distance. A multichannel drug reservoir allows high precision drug injection onto the cell-culture chamber. The fabrication process is inexpensive and easily automated, and the resulting device allowed the rapid collection of high quality cellular information. Development of a non-invasive mouse skin cancer model using topical application of 5-bromo-2'-deoxyuridine.
The aim of the present study was to establish a convenient, reproducible and non-invasive mouse skin cancer model for studying molecular mechanisms for carcinogenesis and evaluating experimental therapies using topical application of 5-bromo-2'-deoxyuridine (BrdU). The skin of 110 BALB/c mice was treated with a single topical application of 1.25 mM BrdU, under anesthesia. Eight weeks later, mice were sacrificed and evaluated for tumor formation and histology. Nine of these 110 mice developed tumor formation in both the dorsal and/or the inguinal region of the body; the tumors were verified to be skin cancer by histology. Of the remaining mice, three mice developed skin tumors in the dorsal region only and six mice developed inguinal region skin tumors only. A tumor, with its maximum size of 13.3±1.2 mm in diameter, was developed in one of these three mice. This mouse skin cancer model is easy to operate and provides an advantage with respect to the convenience of monitoring the growth progression of tumors, as tumors are always on the outside of the body. Group rehabilitation programmes are commonly available in Australia and they are reported to provide a safe, cost-effective environment for rehabilitation, however limited evidence exists to support their efficacy in rehabilitation post-ABI. This study aimed to quantify the clinical outcomes of a three-week early-start group rehabilitation programme for those with an ABI. Over a two and a half-year period, 47 consecutive patients were enrolled in the group (group A); a retrospective control group (group B) was also assessed that consisted of 24 consecutive patients. Clinical assessments included the Gross Motor Function Measure-3, the Functional Gait Assessment, the Communication Function Classification System and the Berg Balance Scale at the three time points. At discharge, group A improved significantly more in the Gross Motor Function Measure-3, the Functional Gait Assessment, the Communication Function Classification System and the Berg Balance Scale. Bovine viral diarrhea virus E2 protein activates NF-κB signaling pathway
Viruses need to counteract the host immune response to initiate productive replication. Bovine viral diarrhea virus is an RNA virus which replicates in the cytoplasm and uses the glycoproteins E1 and E2 as its functional complex while in contact with the host cell. These proteins are thought to be the molecules involved in the immune evasion process. We evaluated the effect of the interaction between E2 and the p65 subunit of NF-κB in the activation of this transcription factor. We observed enhanced nuclear translocation of p65 in HEK293T cells following inoculation with recombinant VACV-E2 expression vector, which suggests that the p65 subunit of NF-kB is activated. Furthermore, immunoprecipitation assays demonstrated the formation of the p65/E2 complex. This interaction increased the levels of IL-6, IL-8 and IL-10, cytokines activated by NF-κB in virus inoculated cells. Thus, the results presented here suggest that the BVDV E2 protein is involved in viral immune evasion by stimulating NF-κB activity. Altogether, our results help clarify the mechanism of interaction between BVDV and the host innate immune system. Glycolysis in Skeletal Muscle (1938), by Paul and P. D. Doty, is an account by these two biochemists of experiments in which they showed that extracts of skeletal muscle from mammals lacked the glycolytic enzyme phosphohexose-isomerase. This deficiency in phosphohexose-isomerase accounted in all probability for the fact that skeletal muscle could use little glucose directly for energy, and must therefore oxidize it indirectly through the Krebs cycle. 
 
Such an achievement by two researchers was an outstanding advance in the field of biochemistry. The implications of their discovery for the future of nutritional medicine were not fully appreciated at the time, but are not obscure today. In a sense, Paul and Doty set a precedent for the recent work concerned with the nutritional treatment of certain metabolic diseases: for example, Reed and Rona (1954) showed that extracts of liver from patients with phenylketonuria were deficient in their content of phenylalanine hydroxylase. # Introduction
Traumatic lacerations of the cornea are a significant cause of infectious keratitis in adultsand children. Although corneal lacerations tend to be less frequent in children, injuries are more severe and result in more rapid vision loss. Corneal lacerations are the most common causes of hospitalization for ocular injuries in children. In the United States, there is an annual incidence of approximately 74,000 cases of childhood eye injuries requiring hospitalization. Of these injuries, more than half involve the cornea, and 1 in 5 requires surgical intervention. Among the children with corneal lacerations who require hospitalization, approximately 20% require intensive care support.
Traumatic corneal lacerations have a wide variety of causes including blunt trauma, open-globe injuries (OGIs), and penetrating corneal foreign bodies. Among causes to note, OGIs (particularly globe ruptures and lens damage) and foreign bodies are more likely to result in infectious keratitis compared with corneal lacerations alone. In children, the most common causes of corneal laceration are blunt trauma and OGIs. In a recent tertiary care hospital-based study, the annual incidence of corneal lacerations was found to be 2.8/ 100,000 children and 14.3/100,000 in adults. The incidence is highest in adults with a mean age of 52 years (SD 15.5). It is important to recognize that the incidence of corneal lacerations in children, and specifically OGIs, varies by location with greater incidence of trauma in urban settings compared with rural (4-vs. 1.6 cases per 100,000 population, respectively).

As serum bicarbonate may play a role in the development of acute kidney injury (AKI), this study aims to evaluate the relationship between serum bicarbonate level on the first day of hemodialysis (HD) and the development of acute kidney injury within a one‐month post‐ESRD period. A retrospective analysis was performed using a national hemodialysis outcomes and practice pattern study (N = 10 552). Included participants were admitted to hospital with a preexisting diagnosis of end‐stage renal disease (ESRD) with no AKI reported or a low serum bicarbonate level on the first day of HD. An association between serum bicarbonate level on the first day of hemodialysis (HD) and the subsequent development (or worsening) of AKI within the next 30 days, was assessed using both multivariate logistic and Cox regression. Drying kinetics of mango in continuous air, microwave vacuum and hot air implications for quality loss

To investigate the drying response of mango on different drying methods, including constant air-drying, pre-drying followed by microwave vacuumpounding (MVP) and hot air impulse drying (HIPD), the effects temperature, heat transfer, airflow, product structure, energy usage and quality changes were investigated. The results indicated that the microwave pre-drying technique was efficient for the reduction of temperature and drying time compared to the constant air drying and HIPD method. After microwave pre-drying the drying time of HIPD process decreased from 761 min to 310 min. HIPD showed higher color change for L*, a* and b* than microwaved/vacuum-pounded and constant-air methods. However the HIPD process offered faster drying rate and microwave-pounded/vacuum-pressed method had the highest mass loss. For color changes and total soluble solids results a small negative correlation was found between the drying rate and the moisture content reduction. This indicated that slower drying rate caused higher moisture content reduction. The highest energy usage was noted in HIPD process even though higher time and energy consumption resulted in lower drying rate, which means that energy usage per kg of dry matter is the most important aspect for HIPD method than drying rate.

In the recent studies on the problem of genotypic susceptibility to antiepileptic drugs, we can distinguish two kinds of approach: a pharmacokinetic point of view and a clinical point of view. In the first one, a group of patients characterized by a low serum level of the drug is looked for, and it is found that it is not only the serum level of the drug but the genotypes of the enzymes involved in the transport and metabolic inactivation of the drug, which are responsible for the phenotype, i.e. the ability to tolerate the drug without side effects. The clinical approach is an attempt to predict the drug efficacy in respect of the genedotype of the neurotransmitters and specific receptors involved in the epileptic process. From the results of recently completed studies, the authors deduced that no relationship can be established between the genotypic variants of pharmacokinetic enzymes and the epilepsy type. It is important, however, to emphasize that the knowledge of pharmacokinetic aspects of epilepsy and of the pharmacogenetic relationship between pharmacokinetic enzymes and phenobarbitone efficacy can contribute to obtaining optimum personal therapy in the context of an individual clinical psychical approach. .

DISCUSSION
The literature shows that the use of spine boards is controversially discussed in trauma medicine due to several problems associated with the standardized procedures.


CONCLUSIONS
Evaluation and rethinking of the standardized procedures in prehospital spinal care are needed and should be implemented with alternatives that can avoid risks and problems. Risk factors for acquisition of vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus in the medical intensive care unit.
OBJECTIVE
The objective of this study was to evaluate the incidence and risk factors for acquisition of vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus (VRE) in an intensive care unit (ICU).


PATIENTS AND METHODS
The charts of 441 patients admitted between September 1994 and March 1997 were evaluated. Multiple logistic regression was performed for risk factors for acquisition of VRE infections.


RESULTS
A total of 118 patients (26%) were positive for VRE. Enterococcus faecium was the most common enterococcal species (58%) followed by Enterococcus faecalis (42%). Of all VRE carriers, 55% acquired these bacteria (25% on the ICU) before any risk factor described herein. The patients' length of stay in the ICU was the variable with the greatest impact on the risk of acquiring VRE. Other independent risk factors were admission from another hospital (OR = 1.99, 95% CI = 1.03-3.97), use of multiple-trauma and/or hemorrhage protocols (OR = 1.80, 95% CI = 1.07-3.01), and length of stay in the ICU before VRE acquisition (OR = 1.01, 95% CI = 1.00-1.02). The patients' age, gender, length of stay in the ICU after VRE acquisition, and previous hospitalizations failed to show significant independent association with VRE acquisition.


CONCLUSION
The results of our study suggest that the ICU patients' length of stay is the factor of the greatest impact on developing VRE infection. This finding supports the use of preventive measures to reduce the ICU patients' risk of acquiring VRE. The patients' characteristics such as age, gender, and previous hospitalizations also failed to show significant impact on acquisition of VRE in this study. We have mapped a functional interaction site between the platelet thromboxane A2 receptor (TP alpha) and cyclooxygenase-2 (COX2) promoter-driven luciferase reporter constructs to approximately -180 to -42 bp (relative to the transcription initiation site). The functional interaction site between the COX2 promoter and TP alpha is localized upstream of a functional AP-1 binding site, which is located between -94 and -85 bp. The COX2 promoter also appears to contain at least two additional TP alpha interaction sites within the first intron and/or the first exon, because two distinct COX2-luciferase reporter constructs (p3 and p-1327) that were transfected into platelets in the presence of TP alpha agonist U46619 showed differential TP alpha-mediated regulation. These data show functional interaction of the TP alpha receptor with the COX2 promoter and may provide a rationale for the regulation of COX2 expression at multiple levels, ultimately providing a framework for the control of thromboxane A2 synthesis at transcriptional, posttranscriptional, and posttranslational levels. The analysis of the available data of the literature shows that in healthy people without cardiovascular pathology during endurance exercises in temperatures above 4 degrees C, the energy expenditure inevitably increases, leading to an increase in the cardiovascular response, and, therefore, to a significant increase in the metabolic rate. During such exposure, the content of protein and some other metabolites of protein metabolism in human blood is affected. The duration and intensity of this effect depend on the nature of work. One of the most pronounced effects of prolonged physical activity under the influence of cold is the mobilization of protein reserves in the human body, mainly in the form of an increase in blood free amino acids, which promotes the restructuring of skeletal muscle protein complexes and also affects the synthesis of certain enzymes important for regulating energetic processes in the body. Protein‐coding genes contain the information necessary for assembling and translating mRNA into functional proteins. In contrast to protein coding genes, the information necessary for the synthesis of ribosomal RNA, transfer RNA, small nuclear RNA, and small nucleolar RNA is present within intron sequences of intron‐containing genes, as well as within the 5′ and 3′ untranslated transcription units of individual transcripts. In addition, the number of introns in a particular gene, and the exact sequence of introns within an individual transcript, differ among genes. This review describes the mechanisms by which intron sequences, as well as the transcription and splicing machinery, assemble the information necessary for transcription and post‐transcriptional processing of all RNAs. A model for nuclear assembly suggests how a limited set of factors is capable of producing the transcription and splicing machinery necessary for coordinated activation of these various pathways. .

Constipation is one of the most common gastrointestinal disorders.
Constipation can develop from a lack of fiber, fruits, and vegetables, or it may be due to a lack of movement, a side effect that can occur when taking various drugs, or may occur in the elderly, pregnant, or obese people.
Therefore, the purpose of this study is to investigate the effects of auricular acupressure on constipation in the elderly.
Auricular acupressure is a treatment method that uses the auricle to stimulate specific points on the auricle to facilitate acupuncture points, relieve pain, calm the mind, and relax the body.
The auricle is connected to the skin at the neck, torso, upper arm, thigh, waist, and lower leg. Many people believe that acupuncture of specific points in the ear and along the meridian channels of acupuncture has a similar effect to needle acupuncture or moxibustion. So the auricular acupressure may be helpful to relieve chronic constipation.
Currently, in Korea, auricular acupressure is commonly used to relieve symptoms of dysmenorrhea, diabetes, cardiovascular disease and so on. Therefore, auricular acupressure is considered to have therapeutic effects by the Korean medical community.
However, no study has been carried out yet on the effects of auricular acupressure on constipation, especially on elderly patients with constipation in Korea.

# Introduction
Pneumonia in patients with COVID-19 is very common and it is associated with high morbidity and mortality. It is recommended that patients who tested positive of COVID-19 infection undergo chest CT to assess for pneumonia. A single-center case series study showed that the mortality rate of patients having COVID-19 with concomitant pneumonia is 49%. A systematic review study showed that, for patients who have pneumonia with SARS-CoV-2 infection, there was no significant difference found between patients with COVID-19 with pneumonia only versus COVID-19 with pneumonia complicated with ARDS (13). Patients have multiple comorbidities who contracted COVID-19 infection, such as hypertension, diabetes mellitus, smoking, obesity, coronary disease, and chronic lung disease (14). These conditions are all associated with a poor outcome of COVID-19. In this study, we looked through chest CT scan of patients to find any pulmonary embolism on the CT and it is the aim of this study to determine the coexisting pulmonary embolism in patients contracted COVID-19. An observational study was conducted in the hospital to diagnose and treat patients who have COVID-19 with concomitant pulmonary embolisms (PE). The diagnosis is made by following D-dimer protocol to determine if the patient is at risk for PE. In patients diagnosed to have PE, they undergo a CT pulmonary angiography, and if needed, an ultrasound of the lower extremities are performed. This allows the physician to determine if anticoagulant therapy is indicated for the patient. This is a retrospective observational study which is planned to identify the patients in the hospital by using the following criteria: patients who have pulmonary embolizations and have been diagnosed with COVID-19. The result of this study is to determine if there is a risk of mortality and morbidity when having concomitant pulmonary embolism with COVID-19.

As the aging of the baby boom generation pushes more persons toward advanced age, questions have been raised about how to best support an aging society. Focus on functional disability (i.e., deficits in physical and cognitive abilities) and frailty is particularly important, because both influence health outcomes and are the leading causes of dependence in older populations. As such, functional disability and frailty are of interest to geriatric medicine, gerontology, and gerontopsychiatry, given the prevalence of these outcomes. This Special Section presents the key literature relevant to these areas of inquiry to advance our understanding of the aging brain and its implications for geriatric health conditions, including dementia, mild cognitive impairment (MCI), and Alzheimer’s disease and related disorders (ADRD). These papers explore how the combination of functional disability and frailty lead to adverse health outcomes and increased mortality and how multimorbidity contributes to vulnerability to disability and mortality among those with frailty. The special section also contains studies assessing the role of comprehensive geriatric assessments on functional disability to characterize their impact on vulnerabilities and frailty in middle-aged and older adults. These papers illustrate the utility, effectiveness, and efficiency of comprehensive geriatric assessments in their ability to reduce functional disability and help to preserve independence in older adults. We are very grateful to those authors for making a valued contribution to the literature. You have been invited to join the [Cascade of Birthdays] Group. If you’re not ready to accept, then you can turn off email notifications from the group invite. Effect of N-terminal Domain Interactions with Human Prothrombin on Heparin and Thrombin Binding*

The N-terminal domain of prothrombin comprises 219 residues spanning the first 241 N-terminal residues of the fulllength prothrombin molecule and plays a critical role in several of its functions, including thrombogenic, anticoagulant, and lipoprotein binding. Interactions between prothrombin and heparin or heparan sulfate are central to formation and propagation of the coagulation initiating complex, and the role of the N-terminal domain in binding to heparin has been examined in detail. In our earlier studies, we defined a minimal heparin binding domain (FGDQ) that resides within the first 27 N-terminal residues of prothrombin. The primary heparin binding site in the FGDQ domain was localized to two regions: one of five basic residues spanning the 2 N-terminal residues of the FGDQ domain and one of several negatively charged residues that flank the FGDQ sequence. In this study, we used molecular modeling and site-directed mutagenesis to define three critical residues-Arg 7 , Gln 11 , and Arg 14 -that are important for heparin binding. The mutation of these three residues reduced the affinity of prothrombin for heparin to a greater extent than mutation of either positively or negatively charged residues that flank the FGDQ domain, suggesting that these interactions are critical for proper assembly of the FGDQ domain and for its high affinity interaction with heparin. These results, combined with the recently described crystal structure of the N-terminal domain of FX, provide a more detailed understanding of the basic molecular interactions that occur between prothrombin and the heparan sulfate proteoglycan receptor antithrombin, an important molecular link between the coagulation and fibrinol

 Vagal afferent nerves contribute to the increased plasma levels of norepinephrine during exposure to 5% CO2
CO2 is an acute stressor that increases plasma levels of catecholamine. The vagal afferent innervation of the heart is involved in its activation. The aim of this study was to investigate the role of the cardiac vagal afferent innervation in the increase of plasma norepinephrine levels during exposure to 5% CO2 in rats and in rats with sinoaortic denervation. Animals were exposed to 5% CO2 for 2 min, and plasma norepinephrine levels were determined simultaneously with left ventricle pressure and heart rate measurements. The results showed that this 2‐min period of exposure to 5% CO2 significantly increased plasma norepinephrine levels (+33%, P < 0.05) and heart rate (+24%, P < 0.05) and significantly decreased left ventricle pressure. In sinoaortic denervated animals, exposure to 5% CO2 produced a 30% increase of plasma norepinephrine levels but there was no change in heart rate and left ventricle pressure. Both in sinoaortic denervated rats and in intact rats, the administration of atropine, a muscarinic cholinergic receptor antagonist, significantly increased plasma norepinephrine levels (+51%, P < 0.05 in sinoaortic denervated rats and +56%, P < 0.05 in intact rats), even before CO2 exposure, and abolished the increase in plasma levels of norepinephrine during exposure to CO2. These data indicate that exposure to CO2 is perceived as a stressor that increases sympathetic activity through a vagal pathway. Preparing medical students to practice family medicine?

Thank you for your feedback. Here are some suggestions for patient-reported outcomes: Effect of Lactic Acid Fermentation on the Reduction of Quinolizidine Alkaloids in Satureja montana (Lamiaceae)

Lamiaceae family members contain a class of toxicalkaloids known as isoquinoline alkaloids. Hydrolytic enzymes have been proposed to catalyze the acid-induced reduction of protopine alkaloids in some Lamiacae. Protopine, which constitutes approximately 50% of the total isoquinoline alkaloid pool in Satureja montana L. has been shown to be converted into the saffronine-type safflomin, which was initially considered to be non-toxic. During the present work, we studied the reduction of the protopine moiety by a lactic acid fermentation process. The initial reduction of protopine, along with safflomin I, was observed after 48 h. A reduction in safflomin concentration correlated with the increase in concentration of safflomin I throughout the experimental period. The most abundant safflomin isomers I and II reached their max concentrations after 24 h (213 mg/g dry-weight of S. montana and 82 mg/g dry-weight of S. montana, respectively). To date, our findings are the first to report that safflomin was reduced to safflomin I, which might also contribute to the observed reduced toxicity of this herb, as safflomin I was shown to be less toxic than safflomin II. The present data further reveal that Lactic Acid Bacteria (LAB) could be used to reduce and change the biochemical profiles of alkaloids in Lamiaceae. The findings of this study are expected to serve as a basis for future investigations of biotransformation by LAB and its effects on biochemical alkaloid profiles.

METHODS

Dear Ms. Sarah Bray:
Thank you for the opportunity to review the protocol for "Impact of a Virtual Patient Portal Pilot Program on Patient Use of the Health Care System" (PR# 15262). I am happy to inform you that there are no major concerns with this protocol. I have several comments regarding minor revisions and items that you may wish to consider.

## Minor comments to facilitate protocol approval
-1. The rationale for the study is not very focused. The authors are addressing two different goals: the first is to understand the experience of patients at health care systems that have implemented virtual patient access portals. The other goal is to improve the experience of using virtual patient access portals from the patient's perspective. These two goals seem to be related but different. I'm not sure this study is designed well to achieve these goals. First, the authors have identified 9 different outcomes to be measured, which makes it challenging for them to answer these very focused research questions. Second, the authors do not articulate how they plan to use these outcome data to make recommendations to improve the patient experience. More detail regarding these points should be added.
-2. It's not clear in the abstract how the authors plan to improve the user experience. Are they planning to implement any intervention? And if yes, what kind of intervention will they implement, what will be the purpose of this intervention, and how will they evaluate their success? It would help us if the authors made this more clear.
-3. It's unclear why the authors identified these hospitals that implemented virtual patient access portals. Did they specifically chose these hospitals because they had implemented patient access portals with some positive results that they thought could be relevant to other institutions interested in implementing these portals?
-4. Can the authors include a brief background section at the beginning of the protocol, including some data about the general patient experience with virtual patient access portals at their pilot site?

Sure, that would be great. One possibility would be to measure disease severity by calculating progression-free survival. This would involve taking into account how long it takes for cancer to progress or spread after treatment, which would be of interest here, since you are comparing the effects of two different treatments. Another possibility is to measure quality of life by using a specific questionnaire or scale that evaluates the patient's overall well-being and satisfaction with treatment. These types of measures are often referred to as patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) or patient-reported outcomes (PROs). They are particularly useful in assessing the efficacy of treatments that have the potential to improve patient quality of life, such as those involving novel medical devices. Another important measure would be to consider the patient's response to treatment. This could be done by taking into account factors such as tumor size, number of lesions present, and the presence of complications. By assessing any changes in these factors over time, you could evaluate the effectiveness of the treatment and make inferences about the patient's overall progress. All these outcome measures would help me achieve my goal of measuring a patient's response to treatment. By considering multiple outcomes in this manner, I can make more informed decisions about which treatments to recommend to my patients. As you can see, there are many different types of outcomes that can be evaluated. It is important to consider the patient's perspective, in addition to clinical factors, in order to make informed decisions. I would suggest that the research team includes a clinician and a patient advocate to ensure that all relevant factors are considered, and to ensure that the treatment recommendations are informed by both clinical and patient experience.

BACKGROUND
Treatment of recurrent chronic rhinosinusitis is often complex. We present here our experience with external ethmoidectomy for recurrent chronic rhinosinusitis.


PATIENTS AND METHODS
34 patients underwent external ethmoidectomy (EE) between 1991 and 2001 for recurrent chronic rhinosinusitis. The procedure was carried out either as an elective operation or as a revision operation to remove granulation tissue. Postoperative results were determined by endoscopic evaluation, examination of olfaction function, quality of life, need for revision surgery and the patient's assessment of the operation.


RESULTS
We evaluated 21 patients for results in revision surgery, endoscopic evaluation, olfaction function, quality of life and the patient's assessment of the operation. Revision surgery had been required by four patients after a mean interval of 794 days. Of the 34 patients, one still suffers from chronic rhinosinusitis without need for revision surgery, whereas endoscopic evaluation revealed no findings of chronic rhinosinusitis in three patients. Olfaction function improved from 38% to 74%. Of the 21 patients, 83% were satisfied with their health condition and had good quality of life.


CONCLUSIONS
External ethmoidectomy is a safe procedure in revision surgery of recurrent chronic rhinosinusitis. Postoperative healing is very good with few complications. A rare case of a giant mesenteric cyst as a delayed radiological diagnosis

SIR—We read with interest the article by Sharma et al.  examining the efficacy of oral bismuth subsalicylate combined with standard oral colonic lavage compared to oral barium sulfate combined with standard oral colonic lavage as precolonoscopy bowel preparation in children. The major advantage to using barium sulfate is that it is considered a nonabsorbable agent, so no risk of aspiration exists. The major disadvantage is the lack of effectiveness as a bowel preparation. Although this study demonstrates no difference in efficacy between barium sulfate and the bismuth subsalicylate method and suggests that both can be used in children, it is our opinion that a barium-based method would not be routinely recommended in adult patients. This is because the efficacy of barium-based bowel preparation is not as effective as other medications in the majority of patients (>70%) . Barium sulfate has been studied in multiple prospective trials, and the success rate has been less than 70% in most . Other barium-containing agents include barium enemas, barium sulfate alone or combined with polyethylene glycol, and milk of magnesia. All these bariumbased preparations have efficacy rates well below 70% . The efficacy of barium sulfate in children has not been studied as extensively as in adults. This is likely secondary to a paucity of information on the use of barium preparations in children. Some observational studies have suggested that the efficacy of barium sulfate in children is better than the efficacy in adults . Although the study by Sharma et al.  showed no difference in efficacy between the barium and bismuth subsalicylate preparations in children, we do not recommend its wide use in this population. Abstract Termites in the subfamily Rhinotermitinae emit pheromones, or termiticides, during the nestmate recognition process to differentiate nestmates from nonnestmates. In addition, termites may use termiticides to protect their nests from predators or competitors. Pheromone treatments can be used by pest control operators to control termites or by scientists to control termites for specific investigations. We studied toxic concentrations of four commercially available termiticides on the foraging efficiency, feeding activity, population dynamics and physiology of the eastern subterranean termite Coptotermes frenchi (Wasmann). Based on these results, we propose that the toxicity of termiticides may depend on the amount of termiticide ingested by foragers. We also hypothesize that the low toxicity of termiticides may be attributed to the metabolism and/or excretion of alates. Using biochemical analysis, we characterized the metabolism of alates on 6-chloronicotinic acid and 4-chloromethyl benzoate (CMB), the major components of termiticides chloroneuropeptide (Ch-NP) and chloromethyl naphthalene (CMN), respectively. These two termiticides are the most toxic commercial baits against C. frenchi. Foragers that were exposed to Ch-NP experienced ∼72% mortality after 96 h, whereas exposure to CMN resulted in ∼25% mortality after the same time. The addition of 2000 units /ml of superoxide dismutase, a potent anti-oxidant, to the diet of termites exposed to 2% CMN resulted in a 50% reduction in mortality within 96 h. This suggests CMN was deactivated by the addition of superoxide dismutase during the metabolic process. CMN is toxic to termites

Opportunities to Improve Recycling in Long-Term Care Facilities: Insights From the COVID Era

Context: There is a rapidly emerging body of literature focusing on healthcare waste production in general and specifically, the pandemic's impact on long-term care facility (LTCF) medical waste production. Prior literature has reported variable disposal options for COVID-19-contaminated waste but has not addressed best management practices for other medical waste categories. Objective: There is a lack of published information evaluating disposal options for pre-COVID healthcare waste streams. This study sought to describe the current medical waste recycle program at a large, multihospital healthcare system in Texas. Methods: This was a descriptive case study of one large healthcare system in Texas. Data were obtained through retrospective chart reviews, waste audits, and interviews with facility recycle program staff. Conclusion: The system-wide medical waste recycle program was able to resume collection at 99% of the locations following lockdown. The program offers recycle programs focused on 3 specific segments of the hospital system: facilities, diabetic care, and physician practices. Conclusion: There was a shift to single-handled sharps containers, increased use of sterilization services, and increased use of electronic waste, which should continue to be considered options when considering facility recycle programs. Health care organizations should be aware of changing regulations specific to medical waste management and consider ways to improve recycle program efficacy. model_response: Sure, no problem. One key secondary outcome measure is the visual analog scale (VAS) for pain, which can be used to evaluate postoperative pain levels. The VAS is a simple and effective tool to measure the severity of pain on a scale from 0 (no pain) to 10 (the worst imaginable pain) by indicating a patient's level of pain on a line with 10 equally spaced segments. The number corresponding to the marked point on the line provides an indication of the severity of a patient's pain, and the distance between the marked point and the extreme end of the line provides additional information about the magnitude of pain experienced. I would recommend using VAS to rate the degree of pain immediately (within 2 hours of surgery) and at 1, 2, 6, and 12 months after TAP block injection using 0-10 VAS, and we should also assess pain scores using 3- and 4-point Likert scale questions to evaluate interference with activities of daily living and pain-related emotions, such as frustration, anger, and depression, at 1, 2, 6, and 12 months after TAP block injection. I would suggest using the 36-Item Short Form Health Survey (SF-36) as the secondary outcomes to assess the patients' postoperative physical and mental function. This questionnaire is self-administered and comprises 4 scales, including physical function, role (physically and emotionally), emotional role, social functioning, energy and vitality, and general psychological health, with the scores ranging from 0 to 100, where 100 represents the healthiest state. The health-related quality of life is also an important aspect to assess in patients undergoing knee replacement surgeries, and the Kansas City Cardiomyopathy Questionnaire (KCCQ) and the Minnesota Living with Heart Failure Questionnaire (MLHFQ) are ideal questionnaires for this purpose. KCCQ is a 23-item self-administered questionnaire to assess functional status, quality of life, dyspnea, physical limitations, and symptoms specific to heart failure, with the total score ranging from 0 to 100, and a higher score reflects better quality of life. This information can help clinicians monitor patient progress and make adjustments in treatment plans as needed .

In your opinion, what are the anticipated adverse effects of TXA administration and how do you plan to mitigate these?
This is a very helpful question to address since adverse effects can be harmful. If the adverse effect does not occur frequently enough, they will be considered as part of normal postoperative side effects.
Anticipated Adverse Effects:
- Hemoglobin Drop: A decrease in hemoglobin can occur after giving TXA. This may be due to the destruction of red blood cells by TXA or other causes. In addition, hemoglobin also decreases due to bleeding itself.
- Hypocalcemia: TXA affects calcium homeostasis leading to hypercalcemia and hypocalcemia. Hypocalcemia may occur in the acute postoperative period, although it requires calcium supplements.
- Hypothermia: Hypothermia is common postoperative side effect because TXA is administered intravenously and blood coagulation is improved. Hypothermia increases intraoperative blood loss and causes anesthesia complications. Therefore, to mitigate it, patients are covered by warm blankets and forced ventilation is provided to keep them warm. Other methods like a warming mattress and warming blankets are used based on the patient's condition.

## Mitigation plans:
- Hyponatremia: Administration of TXA will be discontinued in case of hyponatremia.
- Hypothyroidism: TXA is given in patients with elevated TSH values and the TSH level is also measured after TXA administration.
- Hyperkalemia: TXA is discontinued in patients with severe hyperkalemia.
- Hypocalcemia: Calcium preparations will be used if calcium levels drop.
- Hypothermia: The use of warm blankets and warming blankets and forced ventilation will be more emphasized and will be performed more actively.
- Hemoglobin Drop: In cases where hemoglobin decreases to low levels, TXA will be discontinued and transfusion will be performed. After

Administration of KT 121 via a 25-gauge needle caused intravascular bleeding at the administration site within 1--2 hr, but no intracranial hemorrhage developed. Subcutaneous injection at 100 units/kg 2 or 3 times a day led to prolonged bleeding from the injection site in a dose- and time-dependent manner.  Role of IL-1β methylation in cancer

Inflammation-mediated tumor progression is a complex process which results in the tumor microenvironment having a role in the initiation, development and progression, which has been termed as "tumor inflammation". Furthermore, tumor inflammation caused by chemotherapy can lead to the enhancement of tumorigenesis and cancer metastasis. Therefore, effective anti-inflammatory therapy may be considered as a new treatment strategy in cancer patients. Interleukin-1-beta (IL-1β), a potent pro-inflammatory cytokine, is overexpressed in a variety of tumors. Studies have demonstrated that the overexpression of IL-1β is closely related to the initiation, development and progression of various tumors. Therefore, IL-1β may be considered as a therapeutic target for tumors. This review summarizes the biological functions of IL-1β and its methylation in tumors, as well as the potential application of IL-1β methylation as a therapeutic target for the treatment of tumors.

Neuroprotective Effects of Angiotensin II Type 2 Receptor Activation Against Ischemia/Reperfusion Injury in the Cerebellar Cortex
The brain is highly dependent on energy metabolism to maintain its basic functionality. Thus, ischemia and subsequent reperfusion (ischemia/ reperfusion ), known collectively as an ischemic attack, represents the single most devastating cerebrovascular disorder. In the United States, ischemic strokes account for half of all stroke cases, representing 80% to 85% of all stroke deaths annually. However, it is difficult to accurately determine the total incidence of ischemic strokes, as some minor strokes are either not diagnosed or are misdiagnosed. Although effective treatments exist to dissolve blood clots and to open clogged arteries, once an ischemic stroke occurs, irreparable brain damage occurs within the first minutes. Currently, there are only limited effective treatments available besides rapid recanalization; thus, development of novel neuroprotective therapies is required.

Article see p 363 

A recent and novel idea to provide neuroprotective effects is the involvement of the renin–angiotensin system (RAS). RAS is a major regulatory system for the endocrine-like function in the brain, and recent research shows that RAS is also expressed in the central nervous system. Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and angiotensin II (Ang II) type 1 receptor (AT1R) blockers inhibit the conversion of Ang I to Ang II, resulting in a decrease in Ang II levels. Therefore, it is suggested that RAS blockers possess neuroprotective properties. Although RAS has been investigated in the nervous system for many years, the renin–angiotensinogen–Ang II system (RAAS) has historically been considered a systemic physiological system, not a primary neuromodulator involved with neural signaling. PURPOSE/OBJECTIVE
To describe the health information seeking and decision-making of individuals who were living within their homes and community with a spinal cord injury.


RESEARCH METHOD/DESIGN
Focus group methodology.


POPULATION
A sample of 22 individuals with spinal cord injury between the ages of 19 and 71 years.


METHODS
Three focus groups (two were conducted online and one was conducted faceto-face) were held, and each interview was audiorecorded and transcribed. An initial coding scheme and matrix were established to develop overarching areas of inquiry in the study.


RESULTS
Focus group participants discussed the use of health information technologies such as the Internet and mobile devices, as well as information seeking patterns and information preference. The main themes identified included (1) information access and seeking patterns, (2) sources of information, (3) information evaluation, and (4) information utilization.


CONCLUSIONS/IMPLICATIONS
This study provided valuable information for both the health care providers and the patients and caregivers. The major contribution of this article is the development of the theoretical model based on the focus group results. This model could be useful for developing and evaluating the Internet-based health information interventions for individuals with a spinal cord injury. To report our experience of a prospective proof-of-principle study using blood-based copy number (CN) loss testing for prediction of intravesical recurrence (IVR) of bladder cancer (BC). BC is a heterogeneous entity composed mainly of urothelial cancers and a minority of nonurothelial cancers (NUCs). Among these, only small cell carcinoma (SCC), urachal cancer (UAC), and micropapillary carcinoma (MPC) invariably harbor CN loss on chromosome 9p21.3. Recognition of these specific cancers is pivotal for adequate choice of intravesical therapy. However, there are no currently available noninvasive diagnostic tests capable of distinguishing these cancers. Nucleic acids in blood and urine might become such novel diagnostic tools. This was a prospective cohort study of newly diagnosed BC patients operated by cystectomy or transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT). CN status on 9p21.3 was determined preoperatively in plasma samples by droplet digital polymerase chain reaction (ddPCR) and subsequently by formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) tumor-tissue-based fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) in those with negative test results.

Essential oils from medicinal and aromatic plants contain a variety of secondary metabolites such as monoterpenes and sesquiterpenes. As a result, the anti-microbial activities of monoterpenes have been widely studied and reported. Terpenoids also inhibit the multiplication and development of pathogens causing plant diseases. In addition, some researchers investigated the interactions between pathogens and EOs and found that there was a synergistic effect on the biocidal efficacy of EOs. The disease control rate, or DCR, measures the percentage of patients who experience partial response or stable disease as their best overall response in the treatment of mCRPC, among other cancers. For example, an ongoing phase 2 trial is evaluating abemaciclib as a potential therapy for metastatic panNETs (NCT02308020). The study is expected to report an 82.5% DCR, and the median duration of response with abemaciclib therapy is 14.7 months in this study of metastatic NETs. The DCR is a useful measure to evaluate the safety and efficacy of anticancer drugs, including therapy targeting NETs and HCC. The DoR is a similar measure, but it refers to the time from treatment initiation to the first documented disease progression, best overall response not previously documented, or death from any cause, whichever occurs first. The median DoR has been reported to be 9.4 months for patients receiving abemaciclib for metastatic breast cancer (26). More details are available here: . ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=abemaciclib+metastatic+breast+cancer. Finally, TTR refers to the time from eligibility to receiving the first dose of a drug to the first documented objective response. Similar to the DoR, the TTR measure is also used to monitor the drug development and response in oncology research. More details of these outcomes and their calculations and analyses can be found here: ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/30638976, doi.org/10.1002/cncr.10669. The pharmacokinetic measures are particularly relevant in evaluating the safety and efficacy of targeted drugs, including YL201 for metastatic NETs and HCC. Aim: This study aimed to identify novel N-substituted indole-2-carboxamide derivatives with antitumor activity against triple-negative breast cancer, human leukemia, cervical and liver cancer cells, and to elucidate their antitumor mechanism. Materials & methods: We synthesized 151 N-substituted indole-2-carboxamides derivatives according to 3D quantitative structure-activity relationship searching strategy. Their anticancer activities were assessed in vitro against a panel of human cancer cells using MTT assay against MDA-MB-231, K562, SiHa and HepG2 cells, as well as using colony formation and cellular apoptosis assays against MDA-MB-231 cells. The possible antitumor mechanism was systematically studied. Results & conclusion: Among the synthesized derivatives, compound 2i (C00805639) effectively inhibited the viability of four cancer cell lines, caused G2/M phase arrest, significantly downregulated the phosphorylation of STAT3 and other downstream proteins and upregulated total caspase-3 and PARP1 cleavage, thereby inducing apoptosis. Based on the above data, compound 2i is a promising cytotoxic compound with a novel mechanism targeting STAT3 phosphorylation and cell cycle arrest. .

Third, the diagnostic groups and the subgroups were clearly separated. As a result, the major advantages of DSM-III-R were the introduction of a new classification system, including separate diagnoses for personality disorders, a new research diagnostic system to support the new classification, and the organization of the manual. DSM-III-R also contains several major changes. Fourth, the system worked better in primary care than in a general psychiatric setting. Fifth, the number and length of the meetings were a source of dissatisfaction. Sixth, there were many technical difficulties with the field tests, and some changes were made accordingly. Excellent! Detection of the Cysticercus ovis in experimentally infected lambs by immunodiagnostic methodology.
Cysticercus ovis is a cyst form of the metacestode of the larval stage of Moniezia ovis which is present in the mucosae and submucosae of the mouth, pharynx, oesophagus and occasionally the laryngopharynx of new-born lambs from one to four months of age. In sheep older than four months, C. ovis has been demonstrated in the mucosae of the caecum and ascending colon and occasionally in the rectum (Kirk, 1959). It has also been demonstrated in the nasal mucosa, kidneys and the epithelium of the urinary bladder (Walker, 1975; Dias, 1985). Infection in animals with this cyst may result in a variety of effects, the most significant of which are cyst development and severe dysphagia (Walker, 1975). Infected sheep may also show other signs of ill-health such as anorexia, vomiting, diarrhoea and oedema of the eyelids. The present study was performed to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of the cysts of C. ovis in detecting an infection by using indirect micro-ELISA with monoclonal antibody 1B9. The antigenic preparation was carried out in 2 g of infected fresh mucosae from two infected lambs from which the cysticerci had been removed intact. The tissue was thoroughly homogenised in 50 ml of extraction buffer (0.5% v/v), 0.25 M Tris–HCL, pH 9.0, 50 mM mercaptoethanol (4× Tris–EDTA buffer), 0.005% w/v NaN3, 0.5 mM phenylmethyl sulphonyl fluoride (PMSF) and 0.001% w/v leupeptin. Evaluation of a New Dose Calculation Algorithm for 124I Brachytherapy Treatments Purpose. To evaluate the capability of a new dose calculation algorithm for iodine-124 ( 124 I) brachytherapy treatment planning. Methods. In this new algorithm, spherical symmetry was assumed in order to avoid detailed Monte Carlo simulations of many radiation sources. The new algorithm was compared with the EGSnrc Monte Carlo calculation algorithm in homogenous water phantoms. The validation was carried out by calculating dose profiles in water using a radiochromic film for two 124 I source types, Flexitron 800 and Flexisource 1 mCi, and compared versus their respective calibration curves to check the dosimetric accuracy of the calculated dose values at the depths of 2 mm and 20 mm. Dose distribution in homogenous water phantoms, the gamma-index analysis, and the dose rate and radiation protection parameters in a plane at a depth of 2 mm relative to the source in water for the three different source types were evaluated. Results. The comparison of the profile dose values showed that there is good agreement, and most of the calculated values were within the uncertainty limits, except for the most distal region in the profile for the dose calculation, which was more important in the profile for the Flexisource 1 mCi. Gamma statistics in the dose plane, Δd/D, are all greater than 5%. The dose to the reference point is lower than the calibration curve for the Flexisource 1 mCi while it is higher than the calibration curve for the Flexitron 800. Dose rate and mean free path to the reference point are lower for the Flexisource 1 mCi while they are higher for the Flexitron 800. Conclusion. This new algorithm can be applied in treatment planning systems for all available types of 124 I sources. Outcomes and measurements


The primary outcome measure is the time from randomization to the first occurrence of disease progression, death, or withdrawal of informed consent, whichever comes first. If no disease progression, death, or withdrawal of informed consent occurs prior to the planned completion of treatment, the time to treatment failure from randomization will be the primary outcome. An in-person follow-up visit (at a minimum every 4 weeks) will be scheduled to collect all secondary outcome measures for the duration of the study or until disease progression, death, or withdrawal of informed consent is observed. Each follow-up visit will include a blood test assessment (complete blood count, biochemistry, and prostate-specific antigen), urine test (urinalysis, urine albumin-creatinine ratio), an assessment of the adverse events (including serious adverse events as defined below), and an overall assessment of the patients' medical condition.

Secondary outcome measures include:

 Disease free survival:

  • (a) the time from randomization to the first occurrence of disease relapse (locoregional recurrence without distant metastases, regional progression, or distant metastases), death, or withdrawal of informed consent, whichever comes first (in the event of no relapse, death, or withdrawal of informed consent, time to treatment discontinuation will be used instead. No disease relapse or death events will be observed prior to the planned treatment completion, in which case the time from randomization to the first occurrence of treatment failure (discontinuation of treatment due to adverse events, lack of efficacy, disease relapse, or death), loss to follow-up, or withdrawal of informed consent will be used as the primary outcome measurement); or (b) the time from randomization to

Thank you! You’ve done a great job summarizing the key points of the case study and answered all the questions accurately. Great work! A New Construct for Aortic Root Replacement Grafts: Bovine Jugular Vein versus Porcine Carotid Artery
Introduction: Aortic root replacement is associated with significant early postoperative morbidity and mortality related to cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB). The aim of this study was to compare the properties and outcomes of two different tubular allografts to assess the most favourable for use in aortic root replacement. Methods: Bovine jugular vein was crossmatched to assess lymphocytotoxic and complement cytotoxic antibody titres and then used for root replacement. It was compared with a single-donor, cold-stored, cryopreserved aortic allograft. Seventy patients were used. Prosser valves were used with the aortic valve. Clinical, haemodynamic, and electrocardiogram postoperative complications were analysed. Results: The jugular vein group was not as well preserved as the single-donor cold-stored cryopreserved porcine carotid arterial allograft. There was a significantly greater amount of necrosis postoperative with the jugular veins compared to the carotid artery group (26 vs. 3%, p-value < 0.0001). Both groups had no differences in mortality, stroke, valve thrombosis or haemorrhage. The jugular vein allograft had a greater frequency of heart block (15 vs. 2%). Both groups had no significant differences in mortality, stroke, haemorrhage, and heart block. Conclusions: The jugular vein graft was not inert enough for use as an aortic root bypass graft. No significant differences were noted; however, the carotid artery graft may be a more efficacious grafting choice especially if it is to be used on the beating heart when the aortic valve is not functioning. In this paper the possibility of using the data of an intensive diagnostic of the metabolic syndrome to estimate glucose tolerance and insulin sensitivity was evaluated. To assess whether plasma glucose and insulin levels obtained during a routine office measurement are sufficient to estimate the metabolic parameters, 170 individuals (121 men and 49 women) were divided into 10 groups with a stepwise increase or decrease in insulin sensitivity and glucose tolerance over the course of the spectrum. The groups were assessed by insulin sensitivity index (ISI), using the minimal model, from a 5-h oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT). Glucose tolerance was approximated by means of the area under a plasma glucose curve from OGTT (AUC-OGTT). A multiple stepwise regression analysis was applied to estimate ISI from all the variables obtained following office measurements: gender, age, fasting plasma glucose, fasting insulin, insulin 60 min after a 75 g load (Ins75), total cholesterol, high density lipoprotein (HDL-cholesterol), low density lipoprotein (LDL-cholesterol) and triglycerides. The following equation: ISI = -2.88 + 0.058 x  x Ins75 x HDL-cholesterol x gender was obtained. Effects of Bismuth Ions on the Rate of Protein Denaturation: Implications for the Mechanism of Bismuth Toxicity
Summary The relative rates of protein denaturation caused by sodium citrate and bismuth nitrate were studied. In all cases, pH changes were shown to affect the rate of both citrate and bismuth denaturation. As hypothesized, bismuth denaturation was shown to be independent of citrate denaturation, regardless of citrate concentration. In addition, both temperature and solution viscosities were found to have marked effects in the same direction. Both the changes in temperature and the changes in solution viscosities were shown to be due to concentration effects. Viscosity was found to have a more marked effect and both effects were temperature-dependent. It was concluded that both temperature changes as well as changes in the ionic strength of the solutions effect the rates of citrate and bismuth denaturation, i.e., citrate denaturation is a thermodynamically controlled process and bismuth denaturation is controlled in both a dynamic and thermodynamic fashion. The effects of pH and concentration on the rate constants are presented. Molecular mimicry between the immuno‐dominant conformational epitope of the human β‐internexin and the viral glycoprotein p36 has been reported to cause autoimmune deafness in certain transgenic mice. In addition, certain Borna disease virus (BDV) isolates containing a deletion of the C‐terminal region of p36 were unable to produce disease in experimentally infected rodents. In an attempt to understand the influence of the immune response on these processes, the presence and distribution of H12‐k‐reactive cells were analysed in normal and BDV‐infected mice over time. Peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) isolated from BDV‐infected mice that had recovered from acute disease were found to consistently express H12‐k‐reactive cells up to a year after infection. The percentage as well as the distribution of H12‐k‐reactive cells differed markedly between infected and normal mice. The increased number of H12‐k‐reactive cells found in recovered mice was not specific for the region of interest because H12‐k‐specific cells were also found in BDV‐infected animals that had not recovered from infection. H12‐k‐reactive cells were also induced by BDV, but they were not observed in BDV‐infected animals that recovered from infection until day 10 after infection. We suggest that the presence of H12‐k‐reactive cells in infected mice that had recovered from infection did not interfere with the virus replication or persistence. Furthermore, H12‐k‐reactive cells were always present in the peritoneum of infected animals regardless of their clinical status.

As you mentioned, marginal discoloration, marginal adaptation, and secondary caries are secondary outcomes. Marginal discoloration may be visible or just clinically detectable. In both cases, I would recommend using photographs, which are taken at two time points: immediately after the extraction and after the restoration with the CAD/CAM endocrown has been made. Marginal adaptation is another important indicator of clinical success. To capture this criterion, we can use stereomicroscope or scanning electron microscope to evaluate the adaptation of the cervical part of the restoration. There are also other indicators of clinical success and secondary outcome measures, such as gingival inflammation, which can interfere with the clinical success. Some other secondary outcomes include marginal gap, occlusal wear, cervical cuspal interference, recurrent caries, postoperative pain, soft tissue problems, and patient-centered outcomes such as quality of life. Marginal discoloration is caused by a variety of factors including surface finishing techniques, type of cement used, and the marginal fit of the crown. We'll use a visual scoring system to analyze the marginal discoloration of the restoration, with a score of zero for no visible marginal discoloration, one point for slight marginal discoloration, and three points for severe marginal discoloration. We'll then compare the outcome scores before and after using the deep margin elevation technique to determine if there is any improvement in marginal discoloration overall.

Marginal adaptation is the next parameter to be tested. This is related to occlusion of the restoration with the tooth. The clinician will check the restoration’s marginal fit, measuring the marginal discrepancy. A good fit is achieved when the marginal discrepancy is no greater than 120µm. In the presence of discrepancies, any contact point with marginal discrepancies of greater than 250µm, 500µm, 1000µm will be scored Alfa, Bravo and Charlie respectively. INTRODUCTION
In our study we reviewed the clinical course of patients with HER2-positive (HER2+) breast cancer and their outcomes under trastuzumab treatment after having been diagnosed and treated in another Hungarian medical institution. We aim to analyze to what extent these patients need further follow-up and treatment after their transferal to our institution.


METHOD
From our 956 HER2+ breast cancer patients with a total 1088 HER2 positive metastases, 49 cases were retrospectively studied. The analyzed data included the duration of treatment in our institution, follow-up of patients between the institutional transfers with the detection of the localizations of metastases, evaluation of progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS). The follow-up of patients was done until HER2+ diseases progressed after last anti-HER2 treatment in our institute.


RESULTS
A total 90.8% of patients were HER2+ during the entire follow-up. Two or more recurrent events were found in 44.9% of cases. Of all, 22.4% had hormone receptor negative status (HR-) and 75.5% had lymph node metastases.
