A 61-year-old man underwent radical robotic prostatectomy and pelvic lymph node dissection for intermediate-risk prostate cancer. Preoperatively, the patient had no urine retention problem but was unable to urinate and self-catheterize. Therefore, a Foley catheter was introduced through the urethra after the surgery. On postoperative day 1, he was able to void the bladder and did not require the Foley catheter. However, he was asked to self-catheterize the bladder twice a day to prevent urinary retention and the urethral mucosa from drying out, even without the Foley catheter. The patient returned to our hospital on postoperative day 6 because the symptoms were not improving. A urological examination on the day of admission revealed that the patient had normal voiding function; however, urethral induration was observed. Therefore, the examiner suspected the cause of the urethral difficulty to be the urethral mucosa drying, and the Foley catheter was inserted. In addition, he was prescribed an alpha-blocker. However, since the drug had no effect and he still had difficulties in urination, urethral dilatation therapy was performed twice a week. After 3 weeks of treatment, he could urinate without difficulties and was eventually discharged without a Foley catheter. On postoperative day 42, the patient was discharged and no catheterization or dilatation therapy was required. The patient could eventually go to the toilet to urinate even without a Foley catheter. Based on the findings, we suspected that urethral spasm was the cause of the urethral mucosa drying and difficulty urinating. The cerebrum is a relatively flat surface characterized by only minor curvature, whereas the cerebellum is a spherical structure characterized by large curvature. On the basis of the shape model of the cerebellum and cerebrum, it is considered that the cerebellum has an "inverted-U" curve like the cerebrum. This curvature is expected to optimize information processing. However, few studies have investigated the cerebellar inverted-U curve in humans. To test theoretical predictions, this study examines how cerebellar damage-induced deficits influence cerebellar motor tasks as well as several cognitive functions. We investigated simple reaction time (RT) in patients with cerebellar degeneration (CDe), patients with cerebrovascular disease (CeD) without cerebellar infarction, and control participants. The results indicated that simple RTs were slower in the CDe group than in the other groups; further, we observed a speed-accuracy trade-off for the CDe group. Next, we measured the RT of mental rotation (MR) tasks; no significant differences were detected among the participant groups. Finally, we measured MR error for the three groups. The CDe group committed the greatest number of errors on the MR task, whereas the CeD group committed fewer errors than the controls. Our results suggest that the functional architecture of the cerebellum is a functionally convex-shaped inverted-U structure. This functional architecture optimizes the efficiency of information processing during motor functions and attention.

Abstract Introduction There is limited research on the use of point of care ultrasound (POCUS) in the emergency medical services (EMS) setting. We conducted a scoping review to assess the impact of EMS POCUS, explore areas of practice variation, and evaluate the feasibility of POCUS studies in the EMS environment. Methods PubMed/Medline, Embase, and Scopus were searched (01/01/2000–07/01/2021) to identify articles measuring the diagnostic impact of EMS POCUS or the effects of POCUS education on EMS provider practice. Results We identified 994 citations, of which 21 papers were included in the review. Most studies (n = 13) assessed prehospital POCUS in the diagnosis of cardiac arrest causes, and six described POCUS education programs. Many articles evaluated the diagnostic impact of POCUS without a control group. POCUS led to changes in cardiopulmonary resuscitation and resuscitation plans in four studies, and 1–21% of resuscitation patients’ cases had POCUS impact reported. Overall, studies had short follow-up and did not report long-term diagnostic or procedure impact; however, interventions led by emergency physicians were more likely to have follow-up studies with POCUS impact reported. Conclusion There is preliminary evidence that POCUS influences resuscitation and disposition decisions. Most studies lacked control groups, limiting evaluation of POCUS impact on care. Prospective research utilizing standardized methodology is needed to elucidate the role of POCUS in the EMS environment. Efficient production of biologically active human gonadotropin beta-subunit in recombinant Chinese hamster ovary cells.
High level synthesis of mammalian gonadotropins is critical when making gonadotropin molecules devoid of endogenous non-native components to evaluate the individual contributions of specific epitopes of gonadotropins to their receptor binding and biological activities. Recombinant DNA techniques were successfully utilized to produce the human gonadotropin beta-subunit gene in a functional form in Escherichia coli. The gene coding region was subcloned into the plasmid pUC8, resulting in a recombinant plasmid designated as pHBBB. The recombinant plasmid was then introduced into CHO cells by a single-step method. Twenty clones were isolated by limiting dilution of the CHO transformants, and the highest yielding clone of Chinese hamster ovary, designated as CHO-4. CHO-4 cells accumulated 0.1-0.2 ng beta-subunit mRNA per microgram of total RNA. After 3 days of culture on agar dishes, about 75 ng/ml of beta-subunit of human beta-subunit was secreted into the medium. To confirm that the secreted protein was indeed the recombinant beta-subunit, immunoprecipitation was performed with the culture supernatant of CHO-4 cell followed by SDS-PAGE and fluorography. A self-report questionnaire measuring posttraumatic reactivity was administered to 100 police officers exposed to a traumatic event (an explosion) at work. Subjects were surveyed four weeks and eighteen months after the explosion. Three self reported posttraumatic reactions were measured: sleep disturbances, anxiety about the possible consequences of the traumatizing experience, and negative appraisals of the self. It was hypothesized that those experiencing chronic posttraumatic disturbances would exhibit dysfunctional cognitions and behavior. Sleep disturbances at four weeks post-shock showed high correlations with sleeping disturbances eight months post exposure. <s>I’m glad you found my advice helpful. I do all I can to help other researchers, even outside my specialty.</s>
<s>One of the primary outcome measures I suggest you include in your protocol would be total bilirubin level. Bilirubin is a product of hemoglobin and other erythrocyte components’ decomposition.</s>
<s>Bilirubin is an important parameter for a study such as yours, as it is the major cause of cholestatic liver damage. If the cholestatic nature of the liver damage progresses, the serum total bilirubin concentration in the blood will increase. Changes in bilirubin levels could potentially signal liver parenchyma damage or even death (acute liver failure).</s>
<s>Also, since many of the drugs currently on the market are poorly tolerated in cholestatic patients, it is crucial to evaluate their safety profile for this population.</s>
<s>For instance, if you are looking at pharmacokinetic parameters of antineoplastic drugs, you need to know their effect on the liver. This is especially important when investigating their toxicity profile. Toxic effects should be evaluated on a spectrum in a safe way.</s>
<s>Moreover, the levels of cholatic pigments such as bilirubin can serve as a marker for cholestatic liver disease. They can help indicate disease progression, which is important to monitor in patients with hepatic insufficiency.</s>
<s>In cholestatic liver disease, there is an accumulation of bile acid that can cause damage to the liver tissue. Bilirubin levels can be a good measure for assessing the severity of cholestasis and monitoring the outcome of treatment. It is also essential to understand how long these drugs can stay in blood circulation in cholestasis patients.</s>
<s>The half-life of a drug is another crucial parameter to consider, especially when testing the efficacy of a drug in cholestasis patients.</s>

OBJECTIVE
To investigate the changes of the contents of δ-tocotrienol and δ-tocopherol in the rat brain, blood and serum under ischemic preconditioning (IPC), and examine the protection role of IPC to the brain ischemia-reperfusion (I/R) injury.


METHODS
Eighteen adult male Wistar rats, weighing 280-320 g, were randomly divided into the control group, IPC group and I/R group. (1) Control group: the rats were subjected to anatomical and pathologic examinations and were killed under pentobarbital anesthesia (40 mg/kg). (2) IPC group: the rats were placed on the ischemic platform for 4 cycles for 5 min each. The rats were awaken from pentobarbital anesthesia for 3 days. (3) I/R group: the rats were placed on a cold plate at 4 degrees C for 5 min and kept on the plate for 10 min to get the whole of craniums removed. Then the rats were anesthetized by pentobarbital of 45 mg/kg. All rats were allowed to recover for 24 h, before they were killed under anaesthesia. (4) the serum was collected (at that point the rats were anesthetized by pentobarbital sodium of 40 mg/kg), and the brain tissue was quickly removed and frozen in liquid nitrogen for the separation of brain microsomes. The contents of δ-tocotrienol and δ-tocopherol in the brain, blood and serum were analyzed by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC).

In vivo characterization of the methamphetamine‐conditioned context memory trace in fear conditioning
In humans, stimuli that have been previously associated with self‐administered amphetamines and cocaine have become conditioned cues able to reinstate drug seeking. However, it is not known if amphetamine‐ and cocaine‐related cues acquire similar capacities after self‐administration in rodents, a model that has been widely used to study brain mechanisms of drug addiction and withdrawal. The present study used the standard fear conditioning paradigm to compare these two stimuli, which have distinct pharmacological profiles. A context made fearful by pairing methamphetamine (MAP)-conditioned cues was compared to a cocaine‐conditioned context. Both the MAP and cocaine‐conditioned contexts displayed increased general freezing relative to the control conditions of cue and context‐alone tests. These contexts further displayed dissociable learning and consolidation, as the MAP‐conditioned context was superior over cocaine‐conditioned context in terms of initial learning and delayed freezing. The differential learning capacity of the cues was also detected in the cue response test and may contribute to the differences observed in the learning and consolidation of the cues. Thus, methamphetamine‐ and cocaine‐paired cues may contribute to the relapse of drug seeking differently, through a combination of different strengths of fear learning, fear generalization and extinction of fear responses. Dosimetric assessment of an internal 103Pd/103Rh brachytherapy source using Monte Carlo simulation.
The dosimetric characteristics of the 103Pd/103Rh brachytherapy source have been assessed by monte carlo (MC) simulation based on the Geant4 toolkit. The source was modelled as a cylindrically shaped sphere of approximately 3 mm diameter whose centre is filled by 0.06 mm radius spheres of 103Rh and 103Pd nuclide. The MC photon transport has been done using the physics list Evaluation version 4.5p07 and the electron tracking used the EGSnrc Physics List MINERVA v.2.3.4-02. Excitation cross sections, and energy, angular and dose rate distributions were calculated for the radionuclides in the source material. The energy-dependent fluence and the dose rate distributions in water have also been computed. To compare these MC results with those measured for the source, the photon spectra of the 103Pd and 103Rh nuclei, simulated with an independent method, were used to calculate the energy distributions in water. Finally, the dose per unit air kerma strength in the photon beam, as well as the half-value layers in water and air were calculated for the source with the three methods: MC, independent calculation and IAEA report 708. The results provided by MC, independent calculation and IAEA report 708 are identical for the dose/unit air kerma strength of the source. For the half value layers, there are slight differences between the IAEA values.
